For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles.     "output": "Thought:\n Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to tie \u201cMajorana bound states\u201d and \u201ctopological photonic states\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network (no pure state generation):\n  A) Post-selected teleportation chain simulating Majorana braiding: encode a Majorana parity qubit in two photonic modes, then use two sequential, post\u2010selected teleportations (via Bell pairs in topological\u2010edge\u2010mode channels) to enact the non\u2010Abelian exchange (braiding) unitary.\n  B) Entanglement\u2010percolation across a hybrid lattice: build a square network where alternating links are \u201cMajorana\u2013photonic\u201d channels (simulating a Kitaev chain) and \u201ctopological photonic\u201d channels; demonstrate percolation threshold via entanglement swapping across both types of links.\n  C) Three\u2010node measurement\u2010based braiding: distribute three logical Majorana qubits at nodes A, B, C connected by topological photonic Bell pairs; perform a cycle of two\u2010qubit Bell measurements (entanglement swapping) around the loop to realize a braiding operation on the logical space.\n Step 2: Check novelty and Pytheus obstacles:\n  A) Novel: no prior Pytheus network simulates non\u2010Abelian anyon exchange. Feasible: only linear optics, probabilistic Bell\u2010pairs, beam splitters, post\u2010selection\u2014Pytheus handles abstract qubits and measurements. \n  B) Entanglement percolation in mixed topological\u2013Majorana channels is conceptually neat but mapping a Kitaev chain is unclear in abstract network terms, and would require state preparation in the chain\u2014falls closer to state generation.\n  C) Three\u2010node cyclic swapping is interesting but less directly tied to a specific Majorana braiding unitary; harder to pinpoint the unitary signature in post\u2010selection statistics.\n Step 3: Pick A as most promising: direct teleportation\u2010based emulation of a Majorana braiding gate via two sequential Bell\u2010measurements and post-selection.\n Step 4: This idea is novel because Pytheus has never been asked to realize a non-Abelian anyonic braid via linear\u2010optics teleportation: it goes beyond static entangled\u2010state generation into simulating topologically\u2010protected Majorana operations inside a purely photonic network. \n Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n   \u2022 It is a multi-node quantum network (input modes, two ancilla Bell sources, two Bell\u2010measurement stations, output modes);\n   \u2022 It uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, detectors and post\u2010selection (no cavities, resonances, feedback);\n   \u2022 The target is a teleportation network effecting a unitary (the braid) on the logical qubit, not a state\u2010generation goal;\n   \u2022 It can be encoded abstractly (Majorana parity qubit \u2194 two\u2010mode single\u2010photon encoding; topological photonic Bell pairs \u2194 abstract Bell states).\n \nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe\u2019d like Pytheus to design a linear-optical network that implements a post-selected teleportation-based simulation of a Majorana braid gate on a single logical qubit. The logical qubit is encoded in the fermion-parity subspace of two photonic modes (mode 0 and 1): |0_L\u27e9\u2261|1\u2080,0\u2081\u27e9, |1_L\u27e9\u2261|0\u2080,1\u2081\u27e9. Two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources create Bell pairs between modes (2,3) and modes (4,5), each representing \u201ctopological photonic edge-state\u201d channels. The network then performs two sequential Bell-measurements:\n\n\u2013 First Bell measurement on modes {0,2}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2086,D\u2087.  \n\u2013 Second Bell measurement on modes {1,4}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2088,D\u2089.  \n\nPost-select on the simultaneous \u201csuccess\u201d click patterns {D\u2086,D\u2087} and {D\u2088,D\u2089}. Conditioned on these, the input parity qubit on {0,1} is teleported to output modes {3,5}, but with the non-Abelian braid unitary U_braid=exp(\u03c0\u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082/4) acting on the logical basis\u2014i.e. |0_L\u27e9 remains |0_L\u27e9, |1_L\u27e9 acquires a phase i.  \n\nVisualization (photons top to bottom):\n single\u2010photon inputs: [mode 0][mode 1]  \n Bell source 1: \u2192 modes 2,3  Bell source 2: \u2192 modes 4,5  \n network of beam splitters & phase shifters performing BSM on {0,2} \u2192 detectors D\u2086,D\u2087; BSM on {1,4} \u2192 detectors D\u2088,D\u2089  \n outputs: [mode 3][mode 5]  \n\nTarget transformation (post-selected): \n for \u03b1|0_L\u27e9+\u03b2|1_L\u27e9 on (0,1), output on (3,5) is \u03b1|0_L\u27e9+i\u03b2|1_L\u27e9.  \n\nWe ask Pytheus to find the minimal linear-optical layout (using probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection) that realizes this two-step teleportation network, thereby simulating a single Majorana braiding operation over topological photonic channels."

{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Quantum Clock Synchronization for Future NASA Deep Space Quantum Links\n  and Fundamental Science\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Plasmonic Nanocavity to Boost Single Photon Emission from Defects in\n  Thin Hexagonal Boron Nitride\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Gaussian boson sampling validation via detector binning\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties.     "output": "Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cprojected entangled pair state\u201d (PEPS) and \u201ctopological ordered state\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network (focusing on entanglement swapping/teleportation rather than state generation):\n\n1) Ring\u2010based teleportation network: Build a closed loop (a 1D PEPS with periodic boundary) of Bell pairs among N nodes (a photonic \u201ctorus\u201d). Two opposite nodes use entanglement swapping (BSMs) on the intermediate links to teleport an unknown qubit around the ring. For odd N the teleported qubit picks up a nontrivial global phase\u2014a signature of the underlying topology. This directly uses PEPS connectivity and manifests a topological twist in a teleportation protocol.  \n2) Teleportation\u2010injection into a toric\u2010code patch: Use a small PEPS patch (4 virtual bonds around one plaquette) held by 5 parties. An unknown qubit at Alice is teleported into the code space of that patch via two Bell measurements with two of the virtual bonds. Demonstrates measurement\u2010based code injection (PEPS contraction) and combines teleportation with topological\u2010code logical encoding.  \n3) Redundant braiding via network measurements: Prepare a 2\u00d72 PEPS grid of Bell pairs (no state generation, abstract bonds only). Perform entanglement\u2010swapping measurements along two different non\u2010contractible loops of that grid to enact a braiding operation on a teleported logical qubit. The sequence of BSMs around one loop versus the other yields a phase difference corresponding to anyon braiding statistics in a minimal toric\u2010code PEPS.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & Pytheus obstacles\n1) Ring teleportation is novel\u2014no existing experiment explores a periodic PEPS for robust teleportation with an emergent topological phase. Pytheus can handle Bell\u2010pair sources, BSM measurements, and detectors on a small ring.  \n2) Code\u2010injection via teleportation touches on topological encoding but requires mapping an unknown qubit into a four\u2010qubit code space\u2014this may force Pytheus to target a specific encoded state (disallowed).  \n3) Braiding via network is highly appealing but its full demonstration may need multi\u2010qubit cluster\u2010state generation or feed\u2010forward to simulate anyon movement, which Pytheus cannot do.\n\nStep 3: Pick the ring\u2010based teleportation network as the most promising\u2014purely network\u2010based, extends entanglement swapping, evokes PEPS with PBC, and exhibits topology\u2010induced phase.\n\nStep 4: Novelty  \nThis protocol implements teleportation on a closed\u2010loop network of Bell pairs (a 1D PEPS with periodic boundary), revealing a global topological phase on the teleported qubit for odd loop length. No previous photonic entanglement\u2010swapping experiment has realized a periodic PEPS or demonstrated topology\u2010dependent teleportation phases.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility  \nPytheus can optimize linear\u2010optics setups with probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two Bell\u2010state measurements (ancilla detectors at the intermediate nodes), and number\u2010resolving detectors. It only needs to arrange four or five sources and detectors in a ring and implement BSMs via beam splitters and photon counting. There is no dynamic feedback, no cavities or resonances; all operations are static linear optics and postselection.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nTeleportation on a Bell\u2010pair ring (periodic PEPS) with emergent topological phase\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider N photonic nodes arranged in a closed loop. Each adjacent pair (i,i+1 mod N) is connected by a Bell\u2010pair source. Node 0 holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 that Alice wishes to teleport to node k (e.g. k=N/2). To do so, one performs standard Bell\u2010state measurements (BSM) at the intermediate nodes along two disjoint paths around the ring\u2014nodes 1,\u2026,k\u22121 and nodes N\u22121,\u2026,k+1. Concretely for N=4, connect 0\u20131,1\u20132,2\u20133,3\u20130; perform BSMs at nodes 1 and 3. The remaining photon at node 2 is projected onto |\u03c8\u27e9 up to Pauli corrections. For odd N the cycle\u2019s global phase contributes a detectable sign (a Z\u2010phase on the teleported qubit), directly reflecting the periodic PEPS topology.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/sources: Bell pairs on edges (0\u20131),(1\u20132),(2\u20133),(3\u20130)\nBSM node 1: collects photons from edges 0\u20131 and 1\u20132, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\nBSM node 3: collects photons from edges 2\u20133 and 3\u20130, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\noutput node: detector at node 2 yields teleported |\u03c8\u27e9\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{  \n  description: \"Topology\u2010dependent teleportation on a 4-node Bell-pair ring\",  \n  foldername: \"ring_tel_4\",  \n  num_pre: 1,  \n  single_emitters: [],  \n  target_quantum: [\"\u03b1|0\u27e9+\u03b2|1\u27e9\"\u2192node2],            \u2190 abstract teleportation target  \n  num_anc: 4,  \n  anc_detectors: [node1_BSM, node3_BSM],  \n  removed_connections: [],  \n  bulk_thr: 0.0,  \n  edges_tried: 20,  \n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  loss_func: \"teleportation_fidelity\",  \n  thresholds: [0.9],  \n  number_resolving: true  \n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Vary N for odd vs. even loop length to study the emergent phase  \n\u2022 Extend to larger rings for redundancy and error resilience (\u201ctopologically protected teleportation networks\u201d)  \n\u2022 Combine multiple rings to mimic higher\u2010genus surfaces  \n\nThis idea is novel, Pytheus\u2010compatible, focuses on entanglement swapping/teleportation (no state generation), and opens a family of experiments exploring topology in photonic quantum networks."

Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Measurement-Only Linear-Optical Network for Modular S-Matrix Negativity in Non-Abelian Anyon Models\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an explicit linear-optical, measurement-only scheme that simulates the modular S-matrix element S\u208di,j\u208e of a chosen non-Abelian anyon theory via entanglement swapping and heralded Bell\u2013fusion measurements. By performing a two-copy SWAP-test on the network\u2019s outputs, four-fold coincidence rates directly yield the second-R\u00e9nyi entanglement negativity \u221d|S\u208di,j\u208e|\u00b2, providing an operational readout of topological data using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, static interferometers, phase-shifters, and number-resolving detectors in Pytheus.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. By optimizing the write/read reflectivities {r_w\u2081,r_w\u2082,r_r\u2081,r_r\u2082} to achieve the target average cloning fidelity F_target = 5/6 under a minimum success probability p_min, our scheme fully exploits PytHeus\u2019s optimization framework to quantify the trade-off between coupling strengths and finite photon lifetimes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2). In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nTeleportation on a Bell\u2010pair ring (periodic PEPS) with emergent topological phase\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider N photonic nodes arranged in a closed loop. Each adjacent pair (i,i+1 mod N) is connected by a Bell\u2010pair source. Node 0 holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 that Alice wishes to teleport to node k (e.g. k=N/2). To do so, one performs standard Bell\u2010state measurements (BSM) at the intermediate nodes along two disjoint paths around the ring\u2014nodes 1,\u2026,k\u22121 and nodes N\u22121,\u2026,k+1. Concretely for N=4, connect 0\u20131,1\u20132,2\u20133,3\u20130; perform BSMs at nodes 1 and 3. The remaining photon at node 2 is projected onto |\u03c8\u27e9 up to Pauli corrections. For odd N the cycle\u2019s global phase contributes a detectable sign (a Z\u2010phase on the teleported qubit), directly reflecting the periodic PEPS topology.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/sources: Bell pairs on edges (0\u20131),(1\u20132),(2\u20133),(3\u20130)\nBSM node 1: collects photons from edges 0\u20131 and 1\u20132, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\nBSM node 3: collects photons from edges 2\u20133 and 3\u20130, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\noutput node: detector at node 2 yields teleported |\u03c8\u27e9\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{  \n  description: \"Topology\u2010dependent teleportation on a 4-node Bell-pair ring\",  \n  foldername: \"ring_tel_4\",  \n  num_pre: 1,  \n  single_emitters: [],  \n  target_quantum: [\"\u03b1|0\u27e9+\u03b2|1\u27e9\"\u2192node2],            \u2190 abstract teleportation target  \n  num_anc: 4,  \n  anc_detectors: [node1_BSM, node3_BSM],  \n  removed_connections: [],  \n  bulk_thr: 0.0,  \n  edges_tried: 20,  \n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  loss_func: \"teleportation_fidelity\",  \n  thresholds: [0.9],  \n  number_resolving: true  \n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Vary N for odd vs. even loop length to study the emergent phase  \n\u2022 Extend to larger rings for redundancy and error resilience (\u201ctopologically protected teleportation networks\u201d)  \n\u2022 Combine multiple rings to mimic higher\u2010genus surfaces  \n\nThis idea is novel, Pytheus\u2010compatible, focuses on entanglement swapping/teleportation (no state generation), and opens a family of experiments exploring topology in photonic quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While the notion of performing teleportation around a photonic ring to extract a topology\u2010dependent phase is intriguing, this proposal closely mirrors the \u201cZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring\u201d from the ensemble. That scheme already teleports a qubit around a periodic loop and reads out the emergent geometric phase. Likewise, variants such as the chiral teleportation router on a topological ring cover very similar ground. Because the core novelty\u2014using ring-based Bell swaps to reveal a global phase\u2014is already in prior suggestions, this concept is not sufficiently new for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your ring-teleportation with emergent Z-phase is essentially the same as the \u201cZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring\u201d (and related chiral-routing protocols) already in the ensemble. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new effect or resource not captured by those prior proposals."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We\u2019d like Pytheus to design a linear-optical network that implements a post-selected teleportation-based simulation of a Majorana braid gate on a single logical qubit. The logical qubit is encoded in the fermion-parity subspace of two photonic modes (mode 0 and 1): |0_L\u27e9\u2261|1\u2080,0\u2081\u27e9, |1_L\u27e9\u2261|0\u2080,1\u2081\u27e9. Two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources create Bell pairs between modes (2,3) and modes (4,5), each representing \u201ctopological photonic edge-state\u201d channels. The network then performs two sequential Bell-measurements:\n\n\u2013 First Bell measurement on modes {0,2}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2086,D\u2087.  \n\u2013 Second Bell measurement on modes {1,4}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2088,D\u2089.  \n\nPost-select on the simultaneous \u201csuccess\u201d click patterns {D\u2086,D\u2087} and {D\u2088,D\u2089}. Conditioned on these, the input parity qubit on {0,1} is teleported to output modes {3,5}, but with the non-Abelian braid unitary U_braid=exp(\u03c0\u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082/4) acting on the logical basis\u2014i.e. |0_L\u27e9 remains |0_L\u27e9, |1_L\u27e9 acquires a phase i.  \n\nVisualization (photons top to bottom):\n single\u2010photon inputs: [mode 0][mode 1]  \n Bell source 1: \u2192 modes 2,3  Bell source 2: \u2192 modes 4,5  \n network of beam splitters & phase shifters performing BSM on {0,2} \u2192 detectors D\u2086,D\u2087; BSM on {1,4} \u2192 detectors D\u2088,D\u2089  \n outputs: [mode 3][mode 5]  \n\nTarget transformation (post-selected): \n for \u03b1|0_L\u27e9+\u03b2|1_L\u27e9 on (0,1), output on (3,5) is \u03b1|0_L\u27e9+i\u03b2|1_L\u27e9.  \n\nWe ask Pytheus to find the minimal linear-optical layout (using probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection) that realizes this two-step teleportation network, thereby simulating a single Majorana braiding operation over topological photonic channels.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While simulating a Majorana braid via sequential teleportation measurements sounds thematically appealing, the net effect on the logical parity qubit is simply a \u03c0/2 phase on one occupancy basis state. In photonics this is nothing more than a single\u2010mode phase shifter on mode 1. The elaborate two\u2010step Bell\u2010measurement network with post\u2010selection contributes no genuinely nonlocal or non\u2010Abelian behaviour beyond producing a trivial Z\u2013rotation that can be implemented deterministically in a far simpler way. To be PRL\u2010worthy, one would need a truly nontrivial braiding sequence (e.g. two noncommuting exchanges), multiple logical modes, or a demonstration of measurement\u2010induced non\u2010Abelian statistics that cannot be reduced to a single\u2010mode phase.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposed \u201cbraid\u201d reduces to a local \u03c0/2 phase on one photonic mode and thus is fully implementable by a simple phase shifter\u2014there is no genuine non\u2010Abelian exchange or topological protection. A truly novel teleportation\u2010based simulation would require simulating full braiding operations (at least two noncommuting exchanges) or demonstrating emergent non\u2010Abelian measurement statistics that cannot be emulated by local linear\u2010optic phases."
}

The network then performs two sequential Bell-measurements:\n\n\u2013 First Bell measurement on modes {0,2}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2086,D\u2087.  \n\u2013 Second Bell measurement on modes {1,4}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2088,D\u2089.  \n\nPost-select on the simultaneous \u201csuccess\u201d click patterns {D\u2086,D\u2087} and {D\u2088,D\u2089}. Bell\u2010pair channels and post\u2010selective Bell measurements.  \n  B) An entanglement\u2010percolation protocol on a mixed lattice of \u201cMajorana links\u201d and \u201cphotonic edge\u2010state links,\u201d using entanglement swapping to probe a simulated Kitaev\u2010chain phase transition.  \n  C) A closed\u2010loop measurement sequence on three Majorana\u2010encoded qubits connected by photonic Bell pairs, using three successive entanglement swaps to realize a three\u2010anyon braiding cycle.  \nStep 2:  \n  A) is novel\u2014no prior Pytheus experiment has targeted a non\u2010Abelian braid gate via teleportation\u2014and feasible: uses only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics and post\u2010selection.  \n  B) is conceptually neat but veers toward state\u2010generation of a lattice Hamiltonian rather than a network transformation.  \n  C) is interesting but more complex to specify the exact braid unitary and disentangle measurement order effects.  \nStep 3: Pick A.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it asks Pytheus to find a minimal linear\u2010optical network that implements the Ising\u2010anyon braiding operator U_braid = exp(\u03c0\u03b3\u2082\u03b3\u2083/4) on two logical Majorana parity qubits via teleportation, rather than just generating an entangled state or gate.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only requires:  \n  \u2022 Abstract dual\u2010rail qubit encoding (Majorana parity qubits)  \n  \u2022 Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair (Bell) sources (topological photonic channels)  \n  \u2022 Two post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurements (beam splitters, phase shifters, number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 No feedback, no cavities, no hyper\u2010entanglement  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nWe propose to ask Pytheus to design a linear\u2010optical, post\u2010selected teleportation network that implements a single Majorana\u2010anyon braid gate on two logical qubits.  \n\nSummary and visualization:  \n\u2022 Logical qubits: encoded in dual\u2010rail modes  \n  \u2013 Qubit A (Majorana modes \u03b3\u2081,\u03b3\u2082) \u2194 photonic modes [0,1]  \n  \u2013 Qubit B (Majorana modes \u03b3\u2083,\u03b3\u2084) \u2194 photonic modes [2,3]  \n\n\u2022 Topological\u2010photonic Bell channels (two independent probabilistic pair sources):  \n  \u2013 Bell pair 1 in modes [4,5] (edge\u2010state channel 1)  \n  \u2013 Bell pair 2 in modes [6,7] (edge\u2010state channel 2)  \n\n\u2022 Measurement nodes (post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurements):  \n  1) BSM on modes {1,4}, heralded by detectors D\u2086,D\u2087  \n  2) BSM on modes {3,6}, heralded by detectors D\u2088,D\u2089  \n\n\u2022 Outputs: teleported modes [5,7] (new locations of qubit A and B)  \n\nTarget transformation (post\u2010select on click patterns {D\u2086,D\u2087} & {D\u2088,D\u2089}):  \nOn the two\u2010qubit basis {|00\u27e9,|01\u27e9,|10\u27e9,|11\u27e9} (Majorana\u2010parity states), the network realizes the Ising\u2010anyon braiding unitary  \n  U_braid = diag(1, i, i, \u22121)  \nso that an arbitrary input \u03b1|00\u27e9+\u03b2|01\u27e9+\u03b3|10\u27e9+\u03b4|11\u27e9 on modes [0\u20133] is mapped to \u03b1|00\u27e9+i\u03b2|01\u27e9+i\u03b3|10\u27e9\u2212\u03b4|11\u27e9 on output modes [5,7].  \n\nWe ask Pytheus to optimize over beam splitters, phase shifters, and the two Bell\u2010pair sources so that this two\u2010step teleportation network exactly implements U_braid in the post\u2010selected subspace."
}
