    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible network experiments merging PEPS and topological order (no state generation):\n 1) Wilson\u2010loop stabilizer via PEPS projections (already rejected as known).  \n 2) Ring\u2010teleportation with emergent phase (rejected as similar to Zak\u2010phase tomography).  \n 3) \u201cLogical teleportation through a toric\u2010code PEPS patch\u201d: a small PEPS patch implements a distance-3 code and performs entanglement swapping redundantly to demonstrate post\u2010selected logical error detection and teleportation.  \n\nStep 2: Novelty & obstacles for (3):\n \u2022 Novelty: No prior linear-optical network has implemented a minimal toric-code PEPS patch to perform redundant Bell\u2010measurements that realize a logical entangling channel with error-detection by simple postselection.  \n \u2022 Obstacles: Pytheus can place Bell\u2010pair sources on edges, static BSMs at vertices, and number\u2010resolving detectors. No feedback is needed; error detection is done by postselecting a handful of outcome patterns.  \n\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\nThis network turns a 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch into a distance-3 teleportation channel: four boundary Bell pairs form the physical links, and three interior Bell\u2010measurements (entanglement\u2010swapping) project onto the logical subspace. By postselecting on any one \u201c\u2212\u201d outcome (up to one BSM error), the two far\u2010end photons remain maximally entangled. This is a direct demonstration of topological error\u2010detection in a photonic network without feed-forward or cluster states.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\nPytheus can optimize four probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (on the four boundary edges) plus two more on the two internal vertical edges. Three BSM modules (each two 50:50 beam splitters + two number\u2010resolving detectors) sit at the three internal vertices. No dynamic control: we postselect on runs with exactly one or zero \u201c\u03a6\u207b\u201d outcomes among the three BSMs. The final two photons at the leftmost and rightmost boundary are measured in the Bell basis to verify entanglement fidelity. All components are static linear optics and photon counting\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nLogical teleportation with topological error detection on a toric\u2010code PEPS patch\n\nExplanation:\nWe encode a distance-3 logical channel using a single 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch. Label the four boundary edges of the square as Left\u2010Top (LT), Left\u2010Bottom (LB), Right\u2010Top (RT), Right\u2010Bottom (RB). We place Bell\u2010pair sources on LT, LB, RT, RB (the \u201cphysical\u201d links) and two additional sources on the two vertical internal edges (connecting top and bottom rows).\n\nAt the three internal vertices (the two upper and lower vertices where a vertical edge meets a horizontal boundary, and the central vertex where the two horizontals meet), we perform Bell\u2010state measurements (BSMs). Each BSM uses static beam splitters and two number\u2010resolving detectors and projects the two incoming virtual qubits onto a Bell state (\u03a6\u207a or \u03a6\u207b).\n\nWe postselect on exactly zero or one \u03a6\u207b outcome among the three BSMs. When at most one \u03a6\u207b occurs, the by\u2010product Pauli can be tracked classically, and the leftmost boundary photon pair (LT,LB) is projected together with the rightmost pair (RT,RB) into a logical Bell state. Thus, any single \u201cerror\u201d (a \u03a6\u207b) does not destroy the end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement\u2014demonstrating topological error detection purely by postselection.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   S1\u2192LT,  S2\u2192LB,  S3\u2192RT,  S4\u2192RB,  S5\u2192(top internal),  S6\u2192(bottom internal)\n BSM modules:\n   BSM1 on (LT,S5) & (S1, boundary-link) top-left vertex  \n   BSM2 on (S5,S6) & (S2,S6) central vertex  \n   BSM3 on (S6,RT) & (S4,RB) bottom-right vertex  \n detectors:\n   Four boundary detectors at LT,LB,RT,RB record the logical ends  \n Postselection:\n   Accept runs with \u22641 \u201c\u03a6\u207b\u201d among {BSM1,BSM2,BSM3}  \n Output:\n   Final two-photon coincidence between left boundary and right boundary \u2192 logical Bell pair\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Logical teleportation through a 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch with post\u2010selected error detection\",\n  foldername: \"toric_logical_tel\",\n  num_anc: 6,                           # 3 BSMs \u00d7 2 ancilla detectors\n  single_emitters: [],                  # use 6 probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources\n  target_quantum: [\"logical Bell fidelity\"],  \n  in_nodes: [],  \n  out_nodes: [LT,LB,RT,RB],  \n  anc_detectors: [vtx1,vtx2,vtx3],\n  edges: [\n    [S1,LT],[S1,edge1],[S2,LB],[S2,edge2],\n    [S3,RT],[S3,edge3],[S4,RB],[S4,edge4],\n    [S5,edge1],[S5,edge3],[S6,edge2],[S6,edge4]\n  ],\n  BSMs: [\n    [LT,edge1,\"vtx1\"],\n    [edge1,edge2,\"vtx2\"],\n    [edge2,RT,\"vtx3\"]\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"logical_teleportation_fidelity\",  \n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true,\n  heralding_out: null\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Increase the patch to 2\u00d73 or 3\u00d73 to demonstrate distance-d logical teleportation.  \n \u2022 Tile multiple patches to study networked topological channels.  \n \u2022 Vary postselection patterns to explore the code\u2019s distance and failure thresholds.\n\nThis proposal combines PEPS (virtual Bell bonds and projective maps) with topological\u2010code ideas (distance-3 error detection) in a purely linear\u2010optical entanglement\u2010swapping network\u2014novel, scalable, and fully within Pytheus\u2019s static network capabilities."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node.  Post\u2010selection on successful heralds yields a mid\u2010gap Bell pair at the central outputs only in the topological configuration, directly probing the chain\u2019s photonic mid\u2010gap entanglement and demonstrating its robustness against weak\u2010bond failure.Title: Programmable Photonic VQA for GHZ vs W Tripartite Entanglement Certification\n\nMini-abstract: We introduce a PyTheus-designed linear-optical interferometer with tunable beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors, trained via a classical variational loop to classify unknown three-qubit photonic inputs as GHZ-class or W-class states. This protocol explicitly targets the certification of genuine multipartite entanglement structure in photonic systems and can be implemented on current programmable photonic hardware.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We\u2019d like Pytheus to design a linear-optical network that implements a post-selected teleportation-based simulation of a Majorana braid gate on a single logical qubit. The logical qubit is encoded in the fermion-parity subspace of two photonic modes (mode 0 and 1): |0_L\u27e9\u2261|1\u2080,0\u2081\u27e9, |1_L\u27e9\u2261|0\u2080,1\u2081\u27e9. Two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources create Bell pairs between modes (2,3) and modes (4,5), each representing \u201ctopological photonic edge-state\u201d channels. The network then performs two sequential Bell-measurements:\n\n\u2013 First Bell measurement on modes {0,2}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2086,D\u2087.  \n\u2013 Second Bell measurement on modes {1,4}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2088,D\u2089.  \n\nPost-select on the simultaneous \u201csuccess\u201d click patterns {D\u2086,D\u2087} and {D\u2088,D\u2089}. Conditioned on these, the input parity qubit on {0,1} is teleported to output modes {3,5}, but with the non-Abelian braid unitary U_braid=exp(\u03c0\u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082/4) acting on the logical basis\u2014i.e. |0_L\u27e9 remains |0_L\u27e9, |1_L\u27e9 acquires a phase i.  \n\nVisualization (photons top to bottom):\n single\u2010photon inputs: [mode 0][mode 1]  \n Bell source 1: \u2192 modes 2,3  Bell source 2: \u2192 modes 4,5  \n network of beam splitters & phase shifters performing BSM on {0,2} \u2192 detectors D\u2086,D\u2087; BSM on {1,4} \u2192 detectors D\u2088,D\u2089  \n outputs: [mode 3][mode 5]  \n\nTarget transformation (post-selected): \n for \u03b1|0_L\u27e9+\u03b2|1_L\u27e9 on (0,1), output on (3,5) is \u03b1|0_L\u27e9+i\u03b2|1_L\u27e9.  \n\nWe ask Pytheus to find the minimal linear-optical layout (using probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection) that realizes this two-step teleportation network, thereby simulating a single Majorana braiding operation over topological photonic channels.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While simulating a Majorana braid via sequential teleportation measurements sounds thematically appealing, the net effect on the logical parity qubit is simply a \u03c0/2 phase on one occupancy basis state. In photonics this is nothing more than a single\u2010mode phase shifter on mode 1. The elaborate two\u2010step Bell\u2010measurement network with post\u2010selection contributes no genuinely nonlocal or non\u2010Abelian behaviour beyond producing a trivial Z\u2013rotation that can be implemented deterministically in a far simpler way. To be PRL\u2010worthy, one would need a truly nontrivial braiding sequence (e.g. two noncommuting exchanges), multiple logical modes, or a demonstration of measurement\u2010induced non\u2010Abelian statistics that cannot be reduced to a single\u2010mode phase.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposed \u201cbraid\u201d reduces to a local \u03c0/2 phase on one photonic mode and thus is fully implementable by a simple phase shifter\u2014there is no genuine non\u2010Abelian exchange or topological protection. A truly novel teleportation\u2010based simulation would require simulating full braiding operations (at least two noncommuting exchanges) or demonstrating emergent non\u2010Abelian measurement statistics that cannot be emulated by local linear\u2010optic phases.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose to ask Pytheus to design a linear\u2010optical, post\u2010selected teleportation network that implements a single Majorana\u2010anyon braid gate on two logical qubits.  \n\nSummary and visualization:  \n\u2022 Logical qubits: encoded in dual\u2010rail modes  \n  \u2013 Qubit A (Majorana modes \u03b3\u2081,\u03b3\u2082) \u2194 photonic modes [0,1]  \n  \u2013 Qubit B (Majorana modes \u03b3\u2083,\u03b3\u2084) \u2194 photonic modes [2,3]  \n\n\u2022 Topological\u2010photonic Bell channels (two independent probabilistic pair sources):  \n  \u2013 Bell pair 1 in modes [4,5] (edge\u2010state channel 1)  \n  \u2013 Bell pair 2 in modes [6,7] (edge\u2010state channel 2)  \n\n\u2022 Measurement nodes (post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurements):  \n  1) BSM on modes {1,4}, heralded by detectors D\u2086,D\u2087  \n  2) BSM on modes {3,6}, heralded by detectors D\u2088,D\u2089  \n\n\u2022 Outputs: teleported modes [5,7] (new locations of qubit A and B)  \n\nTarget transformation (post\u2010select on click patterns {D\u2086,D\u2087} & {D\u2088,D\u2089}):  \nOn the two\u2010qubit basis {|00\u27e9,|01\u27e9,|10\u27e9,|11\u27e9} (Majorana\u2010parity states), the network realizes the Ising\u2010anyon braiding unitary  \n  U_braid = diag(1, i, i, \u22121)  \nso that an arbitrary input \u03b1|00\u27e9+\u03b2|01\u27e9+\u03b3|10\u27e9+\u03b4|11\u27e9 on modes [0\u20133] is mapped to \u03b1|00\u27e9+i\u03b2|01\u27e9+i\u03b3|10\u27e9\u2212\u03b4|11\u27e9 on output modes [5,7].  \n\nWe ask Pytheus to optimize over beam splitters, phase shifters, and the two Bell\u2010pair sources so that this two\u2010step teleportation network exactly implements U_braid in the post\u2010selected subspace.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While encoding two logical parity qubits and post\u2010selectively teleporting them to enact U_braid=diag(1,i,i,\u22121) is an elegant mapping of an Ising\u2010anyon exchange to linear optics, in practice this operation decomposes into a standard teleportation\u2010based CZ gate plus local S\u2010phase gates. Teleportation networks for two\u2010qubit entangling gates (CNOT, CZ) already exist in the literature (e.g. PT\u2013symmetric teleportation CNOT, cluster\u2010fusion gates, teleportation\u2010based entangling primitives). The proposed \u201cbraid\u201d adds only a superficial anyonic narrative without yielding genuinely non\u2010Abelian measurement statistics or topological protection that cannot be reduced to known teleportation\u2010based CZ+phase circuits. To be PRL\u2010worthy, one must demonstrate more than a single\u2010gate phase rotation\u2014e.g. two noncommuting braids, emergent non\u2010Abelian fusion outcomes, or topological fault\u2010tolerance beyond local gate equivalents.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The two\u2010qubit \u201cMajorana braid\u201d U_braid simply factors into a teleportation\u2013CZ plus local S gates, which is already achievable by existing linear\u2010optical teleportation gate schemes. A truly novel demonstration would need to exhibit non\u2010Abelian statistics that cannot be reduced to standard CZ+phase operations or show topological robustness under loss, rather than just relabeling a known two\u2010qubit gate as a braid.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We ask Pytheus to find a linear-optical, post-selected network that implements a nondemolition measurement of the 4-Majorana parity operator P\u2081\u2082\u2083\u2084 on four dual-rail photonic qubits by realizing a 4-control, 1-target parity gate.  \n\nEncoding:\n \u2022 Logical \u201cMajorana\u201d qubits: parity of two modes  \n   \u2013 Q\u2081 \u2194 modes [0,1]  \n   \u2013 Q\u2082 \u2194 modes [2,3]  \n   \u2013 Q\u2083 \u2194 modes [4,5]  \n   \u2013 Q\u2084 \u2194 modes [6,7]  \n \u2022 Ancilla photon (single-photon emitter): mode [8]  \n\nGate goal:\n On input |b\u2081b\u2082b\u2083b\u2084\u27e9\u2297|1_A\u27e9 (ancilla in mode 8), the network routes the ancilla photon into one of two output ports (modes [9] vs [10]) depending on the parity s = (b\u2081\u2295b\u2082\u2295b\u2083\u2295b\u2084):\n   \u2022 If s=0 (even parity), ancilla exits in mode 9  \n   \u2022 If s=1 (odd parity), ancilla exits in mode 10  \n Meanwhile the four system qubits emerge unchanged in some output modes (e.g. [0\u2032\u20137\u2032]).  \n\nStructure:\n \u2022 Single photon sources: one emitter at node 8  \n \u2022 Linear-optical network: beam splitters & phases connecting modes [0\u20138]  \n \u2022 Detectors: number-resolving detectors on modes [9,10] herald the parity outcome  \n \u2022 No removed_connections needed between system modes; only the ancilla interacts.  \n\nWe configure Pytheus with:\n {'description': 'Post-selected 4-Majorana parity gate (4,1)',  \n  'single_emitters': [8],  \n  'num_anc': 0,  \n  'target_quantum': /** see expert\u2019s mapping of input basis to output click modes **/  \n  'number_resolving': True,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', \u2026}  \n\nPhysics and generalization:\n \u2022 This gate implements the fusion (parity) operator of four Majorana modes, a central measurement in topological quantum computation.  \n \u2022 It can be scaled to N Majoranas by adding more control qubits and extending the linear-optical network, opening a new class of measurement-driven photonic simulations of non-Abelian anyon fusion.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal is essentially the same as the \u201cOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\u201d in the ensemble suggestions: both perform a single-shot four-qubit parity check by routing an ancilla through a static interferometer and counting clicks. There is no genuine new physics or non-Abelian behavior beyond a standard four-body Z-parity measurement.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The four-Majorana parity readout reduces to the same single-shot four-qubit parity measurement already proposed. To be novel, you must go beyond measuring a stabilizer \u2014 for instance simulating non-trivial anyon fusion statistics or demonstrating parity measurement with inherent topological protection that cannot be reduced to a single interferometric parity check."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. By performing a two-copy SWAP-test on the network\u2019s outputs, four-fold coincidence rates directly yield the second-R\u00e9nyi entanglement negativity \u221d|S\u208di,j\u208e|\u00b2, providing an operational readout of topological data using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, static interferometers, phase-shifters, and number-resolving detectors in Pytheus.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nTeleportation on a Bell\u2010pair ring (periodic PEPS) with emergent topological phase\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider N photonic nodes arranged in a closed loop. Each adjacent pair (i,i+1 mod N) is connected by a Bell\u2010pair source. Node 0 holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 that Alice wishes to teleport to node k (e.g. k=N/2). To do so, one performs standard Bell\u2010state measurements (BSM) at the intermediate nodes along two disjoint paths around the ring\u2014nodes 1,\u2026,k\u22121 and nodes N\u22121,\u2026,k+1. Concretely for N=4, connect 0\u20131,1\u20132,2\u20133,3\u20130; perform BSMs at nodes 1 and 3. The remaining photon at node 2 is projected onto |\u03c8\u27e9 up to Pauli corrections. For odd N the cycle\u2019s global phase contributes a detectable sign (a Z\u2010phase on the teleported qubit), directly reflecting the periodic PEPS topology.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/sources: Bell pairs on edges (0\u20131),(1\u20132),(2\u20133),(3\u20130)\nBSM node 1: collects photons from edges 0\u20131 and 1\u20132, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\nBSM node 3: collects photons from edges 2\u20133 and 3\u20130, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\noutput node: detector at node 2 yields teleported |\u03c8\u27e9\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{  \n  description: \"Topology\u2010dependent teleportation on a 4-node Bell-pair ring\",  \n  foldername: \"ring_tel_4\",  \n  num_pre: 1,  \n  single_emitters: [],  \n  target_quantum: [\"\u03b1|0\u27e9+\u03b2|1\u27e9\"\u2192node2],            \u2190 abstract teleportation target  \n  num_anc: 4,  \n  anc_detectors: [node1_BSM, node3_BSM],  \n  removed_connections: [],  \n  bulk_thr: 0.0,  \n  edges_tried: 20,  \n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  loss_func: \"teleportation_fidelity\",  \n  thresholds: [0.9],  \n  number_resolving: true  \n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Vary N for odd vs. even loop length to study the emergent phase  \n\u2022 Extend to larger rings for redundancy and error resilience (\u201ctopologically protected teleportation networks\u201d)  \n\u2022 Combine multiple rings to mimic higher\u2010genus surfaces  \n\nThis idea is novel, Pytheus\u2010compatible, focuses on entanglement swapping/teleportation (no state generation), and opens a family of experiments exploring topology in photonic quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the notion of performing teleportation around a photonic ring to extract a topology\u2010dependent phase is intriguing, this proposal closely mirrors the \u201cZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring\u201d from the ensemble. That scheme already teleports a qubit around a periodic loop and reads out the emergent geometric phase. Likewise, variants such as the chiral teleportation router on a topological ring cover very similar ground. Because the core novelty\u2014using ring-based Bell swaps to reveal a global phase\u2014is already in prior suggestions, this concept is not sufficiently new for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your ring-teleportation with emergent Z-phase is essentially the same as the \u201cZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring\u201d (and related chiral-routing protocols) already in the ensemble. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new effect or resource not captured by those prior proposals.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nWilson-loop stabilizer analyzer on a toric-code PEPS patch\n\nExplanation:\nWe encode the smallest toric-code plaquette as a 2\u00d72 PEPS patch. In the PEPS language each of the four virtual bonds is a Bell pair. Concretely, label the four physical \u201cvirtual\u201d qubits 1,2,3,4 at the midpoints of the square\u2019s edges. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources emit between detectors:\n  edges: (A\u21941), (B\u21942), (C\u21943), (D\u21944).\n  \nAt each of the four vertices (connecting two adjacent virtual bonds) we implement the PEPS projection by performing a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two qubits that meet there. These are static 50:50 beam splitters + number-resolving detectors (2 per vertex). We postselect only the \u201c|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u201d outcome at every vertex.\n\nAfter these four entanglement\u2010swapping projections, the remaining four photons at A,B,C,D carry exactly the plaquette degree of freedom of the toric code. A coincidence detection pattern among A,B,C,D then yields the eigenvalue \u03bb=\u00b11 of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084 (the Wilson-loop operator). By repeating and tallying \u00b1 outcomes, one directly measures the topological stabilizer.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters:  \n   Bell-pair sources \u2192 virtual-bond qubits: [1][2][3][4]  \n projection network:  \n   BSM1 on (1,2) at top-left vertex,  \n   BSM2 on (2,3) at top-right,  \n   BSM3 on (3,4) bottom-right,  \n   BSM4 on (4,1) bottom-left  \n detectors:  \n   A, B, C, D record the four edge photons  \n postselect: all four BSMs yield |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 outcome  \n output: fourfold coincidence at A,B,C,D \u2192 measurement of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Toric-code plaquette (Wilson-loop) analyzer via PEPS projections\",\n  foldername: \"toric_plaquette_analyzer\",\n  num_anc: 8,                    # 2 ancilla detectors per BSM \u00d7 4 vertices\n  single_emitters: [],           # use probabilistic Bell-pair sources\n  target_quantum: [\"+1\",\"-1\"],   # eigenvalues of Z1Z2Z3Z4\n  in_nodes: [1,2,3,4],\n  out_nodes: [A,B,C,D],\n  anc_detectors: [\"vtx1\",\"vtx2\",\"vtx3\",\"vtx4\"],\n  edges: [[source1,1],[source1,A],\n          [source2,2],[source2,B],\n          [source3,3],[source3,C],\n          [source4,4],[source4,D]],\n  BSMs: [[1,2,\"vtx1\"],[2,3,\"vtx2\"],[3,4,\"vtx3\"],[4,1,\"vtx4\"]],\n  loss_func: \"classify_parity\",  # maximize discrimination of \u00b11 outcomes\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Measure star operators (XXXX) by rotating bases at the BSMs.  \n\u2022 Tile multiple plaquette analyzers to read out larger patches.  \n\u2022 Explore non-trivial Wilson loops on torus by coupling two PEPS patches.\n\nThis network directly merges the PEPS construction of a topological quantum code with entanglement-swapping operations to read out non-local order parameters in purely linear optics.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal to read out the toric\u2010code plaquette stabilizer via PEPS projections and Bell\u2010swap BSMs is effectively equivalent to the \u201cOne\u2010Shot Passive Linear\u2010Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric\u2010Code Plaquette\u201d already in the ensemble list. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new measurement primitive or topological feature not covered by that prior protocol.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nLogical teleportation with topological error detection on a toric\u2010code PEPS patch\n\nExplanation:\nWe encode a distance-3 logical channel using a single 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch. Label the four boundary edges of the square as Left\u2010Top (LT), Left\u2010Bottom (LB), Right\u2010Top (RT), Right\u2010Bottom (RB). We place Bell\u2010pair sources on LT, LB, RT, RB (the \u201cphysical\u201d links) and two additional sources on the two vertical internal edges (connecting top and bottom rows).\n\nAt the three internal vertices (the two upper and lower vertices where a vertical edge meets a horizontal boundary, and the central vertex where the two horizontals meet), we perform Bell\u2010state measurements (BSMs). Each BSM uses static beam splitters and two number\u2010resolving detectors and projects the two incoming virtual qubits onto a Bell state (\u03a6\u207a or \u03a6\u207b).\n\nWe postselect on exactly zero or one \u03a6\u207b outcome among the three BSMs. When at most one \u03a6\u207b occurs, the by\u2010product Pauli can be tracked classically, and the leftmost boundary photon pair (LT,LB) is projected together with the rightmost pair (RT,RB) into a logical Bell state. Thus, any single \u201cerror\u201d (a \u03a6\u207b) does not destroy the end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement\u2014demonstrating topological error detection purely by postselection.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   S1\u2192LT,  S2\u2192LB,  S3\u2192RT,  S4\u2192RB,  S5\u2192(top internal),  S6\u2192(bottom internal)\n BSM modules:\n   BSM1 on (LT,S5) & (S1, boundary-link) top-left vertex  \n   BSM2 on (S5,S6) & (S2,S6) central vertex  \n   BSM3 on (S6,RT) & (S4,RB) bottom-right vertex  \n detectors:\n   Four boundary detectors at LT,LB,RT,RB record the logical ends  \n Postselection:\n   Accept runs with \u22641 \u201c\u03a6\u207b\u201d among {BSM1,BSM2,BSM3}  \n Output:\n   Final two-photon coincidence between left boundary and right boundary \u2192 logical Bell pair\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Logical teleportation through a 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch with post\u2010selected error detection\",\n  foldername: \"toric_logical_tel\",\n  num_anc: 6,                           #     "output": "Thought: While the idea of using a 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch to teleport an unknown qubit with built-in error-detection via post-selected Bell measurements is interesting, it closely parallels two already proposed primitives: the single-shot plaquette parity measurement (\u201cOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\u201d) and the logical entanglement swap on two 2\u00d72 toric patches (\u201cEntanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\u201d). This makes it an incremental extension rather than a novel PRL-worthy target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach true novelty, you\u2019ll need to go beyond repeated parity checks\u2014perhaps by demonstrating a non-trivial logical gate or fault-tolerant channel on a toric-code patch (e.g. one that handles both star and plaquette errors, or implements a logical CNOT) in a single static linear-optical network, rather than just teleportation with post-selection."

Feasible: only linear optics, probabilistic Bell\u2010pairs, beam splitters, post\u2010selection\u2014Pytheus handles abstract qubits and measurements. \n  B) Entanglement percolation in mixed topological\u2013Majorana channels is conceptually neat but mapping a Kitaev chain is unclear in abstract network terms, and would require state preparation in the chain\u2014falls closer to state generation.\n  C) Three\u2010node cyclic swapping is interesting but less directly tied to a specific Majorana braiding unitary; harder to pinpoint the unitary signature in post\u2010selection statistics.\n Step 3: Pick A as most promising: direct teleportation\u2010based emulation of a Majorana braiding gate via two sequential Bell\u2010measurements and post-selection.\n Step 4: This idea is novel because Pytheus has never been asked to realize a non-Abelian anyonic braid via linear\u2010optics teleportation: it goes beyond static entangled\u2010state generation into simulating topologically\u2010protected Majorana operations inside a purely photonic network. \n Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n   \u2022 It is a multi-node quantum network (input modes, two ancilla Bell sources, two Bell\u2010measurement stations, output modes);\n   \u2022 It uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, detectors and post\u2010selection (no cavities, resonances, feedback);\n   \u2022 The target is a teleportation network effecting a unitary (the braid) on the logical qubit, not a state\u2010generation goal;\n   \u2022 It can be encoded abstractly (Majorana parity qubit \u2194 two\u2010mode single\u2010photon encoding; topological photonic Bell pairs \u2194 abstract Bell states).\n \nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe\u2019d like Pytheus to design a linear-optical network that implements a post-selected teleportation-based simulation of a Majorana braid gate on a single logical qubit. The network then performs two sequential Bell-measurements:\n\n\u2013 First Bell measurement on modes {0,2}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2086,D\u2087.  \n\u2013 Second Bell measurement on modes {1,4}, heralded by ancilla detectors D\u2088,D\u2089.  \n\nPost-select on the simultaneous \u201csuccess\u201d click patterns {D\u2086,D\u2087} and {D\u2088,D\u2089}.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: I want to propose a linear-optical network that simulates the non-commutativity of two Majorana braids by coherently superposing two teleportation orders (\u201cA then B\u201d vs. \u201cB then A\u201d) over topological-photonic Bell channels and reading out their relative phase. This goes beyond trivial gate implementation because the two-order superposition exhibits a braiding signature that cannot be reduced to a single CZ+phase.  \nStep 2: This is novel\u2014no existing Pytheus experiment builds a coherent superposition of two teleportation sequences to probe non-Abelian statistics.  \nStep 3: It is feasible in Pytheus: we only need probabilistic Bell-pair sources, static beam splitters, phase shifters, number-resolving detectors, and no feedback. The input photon is split into two paths; each path carries out two sequential post-selected Bell measurements in opposite orders; finally the two paths recombine interferometrically and a characteristic phase shift is heralded by a joint click pattern.  \nStep 4: This network targets a transformation\u2014superposed teleportation orders yielding a relative i-phase difference\u2014rather than state generation, and naturally generalizes to more channels (i.e. simulating longer braiding sequences).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a static linear-optical network that demonstrates the non-commutativity of two Ising-anyon braids by coherently superposing two teleportation orders over topological-photonic Bell channels.\n\n1) Encoding:\n \u2022 Logical qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 in dual-rail modes [0,1].  \n \u2022 Two \u201ctopological photonic\u201d Bell channels: Bell pair 1 on modes [2,3] (\u201cA\u201d), Bell pair 2 on modes [4,5] (\u201cB\u201d).  \n\n2) Network outline:\n \u2022 A 50/50 beam splitter splits the input qubit [0,1] into two spatial paths P and Q.  \n \u2022 Path P: perform post-selected teleportation first via channel A then B:  \n   \u2013 BSM_A on modes {P-0, 2}, heralded by detectors D\u2086,D\u2087  \n   \u2013 BSM_B on modes {output of A teleport, 4}, heralded by D\u2088,D\u2089  \n   \u2192 output mode P_out  \n \u2022 Path Q: perform teleportation first via B then A:  \n   \u2013 BSM_B on {Q-1, 4}, heralded by D\u2081\u2080,D\u2081\u2081  \n   \u2013 BSM_A on {output of B teleport, 2}, heralded by D\u2081\u2082,D\u2081\u2083  \n   \u2192 output mode Q_out  \n \u2022 Recombine P_out & Q_out on a final beam splitter + phase shifter network, then detect on output ports D\u2081\u2084,D\u2081\u2085.  \n\n3) Post-selection:\n Condition on simultaneous click patterns at {D\u2086\u2013D\u2089} and {D\u2081\u2080\u2013D\u2081\u2083} (the four BSM heralds) and one click at either D\u2081\u2084 or D\u2081\u2085.  \n\n4) Target transformation:\n In the post-selected subspace, the network implements the superposition of two teleportation orders. The output amplitude on D\u2081\u2084 vs. D\u2081\u2085 carries a relative phase \u03c6 = \u03c0/2, signature of U_B U_A \u2260 U_A U_B, i.e. the non-Abelian braid phase of two Ising anyons.  \n\nConfiguration hints for Pytheus:\n {'description':'Superposed teleportation orders (\u201cA\u2192B\u201d vs. \u201cB\u2192A\u201d) to simulate a Majorana braid','bulk_thr':0.01,'edges_tried':30,'loss_func':'cr','number_resolving':True,  \n  'target_quantum':/** abstract mapping of the 2-path interferometer\u2019s click patterns to a \u03c0/2 phase shift **/,  \n  'single_emitters':[],'heralding_out':None,  \n  'removed_connections':[],\u2026}  \n\nPhysics and generalization:\n \u2022 This network probes non-commutativity (braid statistics) rather than just enacting a static gate.  \n \u2022 One can generalize to N sequential channels (A,B,C,\u2026) and superpose all N! teleportation orders, exploring richer non-Abelian groups.  \n \u2022 All elements (Bell pairs, BSM modules, beam splitters, phase shifters, detectors) are within Pytheus\u2019s design scope\u2014no cavities, feedback, or hyper-entanglement required."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node.  Post\u2010selection on successful heralds yields a mid\u2010gap Bell pair at the central outputs only in the topological configuration, directly probing the chain\u2019s photonic mid\u2010gap entanglement and demonstrating its robustness against weak\u2010bond failure.Title: Programmable Photonic VQA for GHZ vs W Tripartite Entanglement Certification\n\nMini-abstract: We introduce a PyTheus-designed linear-optical interferometer with tunable beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors, trained via a classical variational loop to classify unknown three-qubit photonic inputs as GHZ-class or W-class states. This protocol explicitly targets the certification of genuine multipartite entanglement structure in photonic systems and can be implemented on current programmable photonic hardware.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Mode\u2010Division\u2010Multiplexed On\u2010Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We propose an integrated\u2010optics node that purifies two probabilistic qutrit photon\u2010pair sources into the target high\u2010fidelity 3-dimensional Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9 by routing Alice\u2019s spatial modes and Bob\u2019s mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed channels through a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optic parity\u2010check circuit with two ancilla heralding detectors. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively.
