Classical by-product corrections are tracked offline.\n\u2022 Verification: measure a Bell-fidelity between the two output photons in the computational basis, confirming the CNOT action.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters:  E1\u2192A_left, E2\u2192B_left  \n sources:   S1,S2,S3 on A boundary; S4,S5 on B boundary; S6,S7 on internal links  \n BSMs:      M1\u2026M6 at the six vertices  \n detectors: D1\u2192A_right, D2\u2192B_right; ancilla detectors at M1\u2026M6  \n\nPytheus\u2010config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Logical CNOT via two adjacent 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patches\",\n  foldername: \"toric_peps_logical_cnot\",\n  single_emitters: [E1,E2],          # input qubits\n  num_anc: 12,                       # 6 BSMs \u00d7 2 detectors\n  anc_detectors: [M1,M2,M3,M4,M5,M6],\n  edges: [\n    [S1,A_edge1],[S1,A_edge2],\n    [S2,A_edge3],[S2,A_edge4],\n    [S3,A_edge5],[S3,A_edge6],\n    [S4,B_edge1],[S4,B_edge2],\n    [S5,B_edge3],[S5,B_edge4],\n    [S6,A_int],[S6,A_int_peer],\n    [S7,B_int],[S7,B_int_peer]\n  ],\n  BSMs: [\n    [A_edge1,A_int,\"M1\"],[A_int,A_edge2,\"M2\"],\n    [A_edge3,A_edge4,\"M3\"],[B_edge1,B_int,\"M4\"],\n    [B_int,B_edge2,\"M5\"],[B_edge3,B_edge4,\"M6\"]\n  ],\n  out_nodes: [D1,D2],                # right boundary outputs\n  loss_func: \"cnot_fidelity\",       # maximize mapping fidelity to CNOT truth table\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Scale to larger patches (distance-d codes) for multi-error tolerance in logical gates.  \n \u2022 Implement other logical Clifford gates (CZ, Hadamard) by changing which virtual bonds are measured.  \n \u2022 Tile multiple patches to build a network of topologically fault-tolerant logical channels.\n\nThis experiment weaves together PEPS constructions, topological error-detection, and entanglement-swapping teleportation to realize a logical CNOT in a single passive, static photonic network\u2014fully compatible with Pytheus and opening a new class of topological quantum\u2010network transformations.\n\nJudge Feedback: The core reliance on preparing toric\u2010code PEPS patches makes this protocol effectively a hard state\u2010generation problem beyond the intended scope, and the extensive resource overhead and error management steps undermine its practical feasibility.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to fuse \u201cprojected entangled pair state\u201d and \u201ctopological ordered state\u201d into a purely network-based experiment (no new state generation, only entanglement swapping/teleportation).\n 1) Static measurement of a toric-code plaquette via Bell-swap projections (already seen in parity-check proposals).  \n 2) Teleportation on a 1D PEPS ring with emergent topological phase (too similar to Zak-phase tomography).  \n 3) Measurement-induced topological percolation on a PEPS network: use a 2D torus (PEPS of Bell bonds) and selective Bell-measurements (entanglement swapping) to drive non-contractible entanglement paths; map out a percolation-like threshold for long-range teleportation across two non-homotopic loops.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & obstacles\n\u2022 Idea 3 is novel: no prior experiment uses Bell-pair lattices + swapping to explore topologically nontrivial entanglement percolation.  \n\u2022 Pytheus can place probabilistic Bell sources on graph edges, static BSM modules (beam splitters + number-resolving detectors) at chosen vertices, and optimize for high teleportation fidelity between two distant nodes.\n\nStep 3: Pick idea 3.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it turns a 2D PEPS (Bell-pair lattice) into a \u201cmeasurement-induced topological network,\u201d where one witnesses the emergence of long-range entangled channels along noncontractible loops on a torus. No existing photonic linear-optics experiment has mapped out such a topological percolation/phase transition via entanglement swapping.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because:\n \u2022 All resources are probabilistic Bell-pair sources and static Bell-state measurements\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n \u2022 The target is simply \u201cmaximally entangle node A to node B across a given homotopy class,\u201d which Pytheus can optimize via its linear-optics graph search.  \n \u2022 The configuration can be varied in size (3\u00d73, 4\u00d74, \u2026) and in pattern of swaps, providing a family of experiments.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nMeasurement-Induced Topological Percolation in a Bell-Pair Torus\n\nExplanation:\nWe take an L\u00d7L toroidal lattice of photonic nodes. Each edge carries a Bell pair from a probabilistic source. Two opposite nodes, A and B, are chosen as \u201cboundaries\u201d between which we wish to teleport an unknown qubit. To do so, we perform Bell-state measurements (BSMs) on a subset of edges that forms a path on the dual lattice. When that path winds around a noncontractible cycle of the torus, A and B become entangled via entanglement swapping along that loop.\n\nBy varying which edges are measured (and how many), one can map out a \u201cpercolation threshold\u201d p_c: the minimum density of BSMs required to achieve high-fidelity teleportation around each independent cycle. Pytheus\u2019s job is to find, for each loop (say the \u201cmeridional\u201d and \u201clongitudinal\u201d directions), the optimal static LO network (choice of beam splitters and detectors) that maximizes teleportation fidelity between A and B using only k BSMs. Repeating for k=1\u2026K traces out the onset of topological connectivity.\n\nVisualization (for L=3):\n\u2013 Emitters/sources: Bell pairs on all 18 edges of a 3\u00d73 torus (edges wrap around).  \n\u2013 BSM modules: placed on k selected edges forming a continuous loop from A back to B along one homotopy class; each BSM is a 50:50 beam splitter + two number-resolving detectors.  \n\u2013 Input qubit: encoded on one half of the Bell pair at node A.  \n\u2013 Output qubit: recovered on the other half at node B after all k BSMs.  \n\u2013 Postselection: keep runs where every BSM clicks once. Measure fidelity of teleportation from A\u2192B.\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Topological percolation on a 3\u00d73 Bell-pair torus\",\n  foldername: \"torus_percolation_3\",\n  single_emitters: [],                    \n  num_anc: 2*k,                           # two ancilla detectors per BSM \u00d7 k swaps\n  anc_detectors: [\"bsm1\",\u2026,\"bsmk\"],\n  edges: [ all 18 Bell-pair source connections ],\n  BSMs: [ [u1,v1,\"bsm1\"], \u2026, [uk,vk,\"bsmk\"] ], # selected edges forming a noncontractible loop\n  in_nodes: [A_in],                      \n  out_nodes: [B_out],\n  loss_func: \"teleportation_fidelity\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Vary L to study finite-size scaling of p_c.  \n\u2013 Compare the two independent cycles (meridian vs. longitude).  \n\u2013 Extend to random BSM patterns for measurement-induced disorder.  \n\u2013 Explore interplay between lattice geometry (hexagonal, kagome) and percolation.\n\nThis family of experiments concretely merges the PEPS picture (Bell bonds on a torus) with topological order (noncontractible loops), using only static entanglement-swapping networks to reveal a measurement-induced topological transition."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. By performing a two-copy SWAP-test on the network\u2019s outputs, four-fold coincidence rates directly yield the second-R\u00e9nyi entanglement negativity \u221d|S\u208di,j\u208e|\u00b2, providing an operational readout of topological data using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, static interferometers, phase-shifters, and number-resolving detectors in Pytheus.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nTeleportation on a Bell\u2010pair ring (periodic PEPS) with emergent topological phase\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider N photonic nodes arranged in a closed loop. Each adjacent pair (i,i+1 mod N) is connected by a Bell\u2010pair source. Node 0 holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 that Alice wishes to teleport to node k (e.g. k=N/2). To do so, one performs standard Bell\u2010state measurements (BSM) at the intermediate nodes along two disjoint paths around the ring\u2014nodes 1,\u2026,k\u22121 and nodes N\u22121,\u2026,k+1. Concretely for N=4, connect 0\u20131,1\u20132,2\u20133,3\u20130; perform BSMs at nodes 1 and 3. The remaining photon at node 2 is projected onto |\u03c8\u27e9 up to Pauli corrections. For odd N the cycle\u2019s global phase contributes a detectable sign (a Z\u2010phase on the teleported qubit), directly reflecting the periodic PEPS topology.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/sources: Bell pairs on edges (0\u20131),(1\u20132),(2\u20133),(3\u20130)\nBSM node 1: collects photons from edges 0\u20131 and 1\u20132, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\nBSM node 3: collects photons from edges 2\u20133 and 3\u20130, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\noutput node: detector at node 2 yields teleported |\u03c8\u27e9\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{  \n  description: N for odd vs. even loop length to study the emergent phase  \n\u2022 Extend to larger rings for redundancy and error resilience (\u201ctopologically protected teleportation networks\u201d)  \n\u2022 Combine multiple rings to mimic higher\u2010genus surfaces  \n\nThis idea is novel, Pytheus\u2010compatible, focuses on entanglement swapping/teleportation (no state generation), and opens a family of experiments exploring topology in photonic quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the notion of performing teleportation around a photonic ring to extract a topology\u2010dependent phase is intriguing, this proposal closely mirrors the \u201cZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring\u201d from the ensemble. That scheme already teleports a qubit around a periodic loop and reads out the emergent geometric phase. Likewise, variants such as the chiral teleportation router on a topological ring cover very similar ground. Because the core novelty\u2014using ring-based Bell swaps to reveal a global phase\u2014is already in prior suggestions, this concept is not sufficiently new for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your ring-teleportation with emergent Z-phase is essentially the same as the \u201cZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring\u201d (and related chiral-routing protocols) already in the ensemble. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new effect or resource not captured by those prior proposals.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nWilson-loop stabilizer analyzer on a toric-code PEPS patch\n\nExplanation:\nWe encode the smallest toric-code plaquette as a 2\u00d72 PEPS patch. In the PEPS language each of the four virtual bonds is a Bell pair. Concretely, label the four physical \u201cvirtual\u201d qubits 1,2,3,4 at the midpoints of the square\u2019s edges. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources emit between detectors:\n  edges: (A\u21941), (B\u21942), (C\u21943), (D\u21944).\n  \nAt each of the four vertices (connecting two adjacent virtual bonds) we implement the PEPS projection by performing a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two qubits that meet there. These are static 50:50 beam splitters + number-resolving detectors (2 per vertex). We postselect only the \u201c|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u201d outcome at every vertex.\n\nAfter these four entanglement\u2010swapping projections, the remaining four photons at A,B,C,D carry exactly the plaquette degree of freedom of the toric code. A coincidence detection pattern among A,B,C,D then yields the eigenvalue \u03bb=\u00b11 of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084 (the Wilson-loop operator). By repeating and tallying \u00b1 outcomes, one directly measures the topological stabilizer.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters:  \n   Bell-pair sources \u2192 virtual-bond qubits: [1][2][3][4]  \n projection network:  \n   BSM1 on (1,2) at top-left vertex,  \n   BSM2 on (2,3) at top-right,  \n   BSM3 on (3,4) bottom-right,  \n   BSM4 on (4,1) bottom-left  \n detectors:  \n   A, B, C, D record the four edge photons  \n postselect: all four BSMs yield |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 outcome  \n output: fourfold coincidence at A,B,C,D \u2192 measurement of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Toric-code plaquette (Wilson-loop) analyzer via PEPS projections\",\n  foldername: \"toric_plaquette_analyzer\",\n  num_anc: 8,                    # 2 ancilla detectors per BSM \u00d7 4 vertices\n  single_emitters: [],           # use probabilistic Bell-pair sources\n  target_quantum: [\"+1\",\"-1\"],   # eigenvalues of Z1Z2Z3Z4\n  in_nodes: [1,2,3,4],\n  out_nodes: [A,B,C,D],\n  anc_detectors: [\"vtx1\",\"vtx2\",\"vtx3\",\"vtx4\"],\n  edges: [[source1,1],[source1,A],\n          [source2,2],[source2,B],\n          [source3,3],[source3,C],\n          [source4,4],[source4,D]],\n  BSMs: [[1,2,\"vtx1\"],[2,3,\"vtx2\"],[3,4,\"vtx3\"],[4,1,\"vtx4\"]],\n  loss_func: \"classify_parity\",  # maximize discrimination of \u00b11 outcomes\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Measure star operators (XXXX) by rotating bases at the BSMs.  \n\u2022 Tile multiple plaquette analyzers to read out larger patches.  \n\u2022 Explore non-trivial Wilson loops on torus by coupling two PEPS patches.\n\nThis network directly merges the PEPS construction of a topological quantum code with entanglement-swapping operations to read out non-local order parameters in purely linear optics.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal to read out the toric\u2010code plaquette stabilizer via PEPS projections and Bell\u2010swap BSMs is effectively equivalent to the \u201cOne\u2010Shot Passive Linear\u2010Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric\u2010Code Plaquette\u201d already in the ensemble list. Label the four boundary edges of the square as Left\u2010Top (LT), Left\u2010Bottom (LB), Right\u2010Top (RT), Right\u2010Bottom (RB). We place Bell\u2010pair sources on LT, LB, RT, RB (the \u201cphysical\u201d links) and two additional sources on the two vertical internal edges (connecting top and bottom rows).\n\nAt the three internal vertices (the two upper and lower vertices where a vertical edge meets a horizontal boundary, and the central vertex where the two horizontals meet), we perform Bell\u2010state measurements (BSMs). Each BSM uses static beam splitters and two number\u2010resolving detectors and projects the two incoming virtual qubits onto a Bell state (\u03a6\u207a or \u03a6\u207b).\n\nWe postselect on exactly zero or one \u03a6\u207b outcome among the three BSMs. When at most one \u03a6\u207b occurs, the by\u2010product Pauli can be tracked classically, and the leftmost boundary photon pair (LT,LB) is projected together with the rightmost pair (RT,RB) into a logical Bell state. Thus, any single \u201cerror\u201d (a \u03a6\u207b) does not destroy the end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement\u2014demonstrating topological error detection purely by postselection.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   S1\u2192LT,  S2\u2192LB,  S3\u2192RT,  S4\u2192RB,  S5\u2192(top internal),  S6\u2192(bottom internal)\n BSM modules:\n   BSM1 on (LT,S5) & (S1, boundary-link) top-left vertex  \n   BSM2 on (S5,S6) & (S2,S6) central vertex  \n   BSM3 on (S6,RT) & (S4,RB) bottom-right vertex  \n detectors:\n   Four boundary detectors at LT,LB,RT,RB record the logical ends  \n Postselection:\n   Accept runs with \u22641 \u201c\u03a6\u207b\u201d among {BSM1,BSM2,BSM3}  \n Output:\n   Final two-photon coincidence between left boundary and right boundary \u2192 logical Bell pair\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Logical teleportation through a 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch with post\u2010selected error detection\",\n  foldername: \"toric_logical_tel\",\n  num_anc: 6,                           # Each edge carries a Bell pair from a probabilistic source. Two opposite nodes, A and B, are chosen as \u201cboundaries\u201d between which we wish to teleport an unknown qubit. To do so, we perform Bell-state measurements (BSMs) on a subset of edges that forms a path on the dual lattice. When that path winds around a noncontractible cycle of the torus, A and B become entangled via entanglement swapping along that loop.\n\nBy varying which edges are measured (and how many), one can map out a \u201cpercolation threshold\u201d p_c: the minimum density of BSMs required to achieve high-fidelity teleportation around each independent cycle. Pytheus\u2019s job is to find, for each loop (say the \u201cmeridional\u201d and \u201clongitudinal\u201d directions), the optimal static LO network (choice of beam splitters and detectors) that maximizes teleportation fidelity between A and B using only k BSMs. Repeating for k=1\u2026K traces out the onset of topological connectivity.\n\nVisualization (for L=3):\n\u2013 Emitters/sources: Bell pairs on all 18 edges of a 3\u00d73 torus (edges wrap around).  \n\u2013 BSM modules: placed on k selected edges forming a continuous loop from A back to B along one homotopy class; each BSM is a 50:50 beam splitter + two number-resolving detectors.  \n\u2013 Input qubit: encoded on one half of the Bell pair at node A.  \n\u2013 Output qubit: recovered on the other half at node B after all k BSMs.  \n\u2013 Postselection: keep runs where every BSM clicks once. Measure fidelity of teleportation from A\u2192B.\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Topological percolation on a 3\u00d73 Bell-pair torus\",\n  foldername: \"torus_percolation_3\",\n  single_emitters: [],                    \n  num_anc: 2*k,                           # two ancilla detectors per BSM \u00d7 k swaps\n  anc_detectors: [\"bsm1\",\u2026,\"bsmk\"],\n  edges: [ all 18 Bell-pair source connections ],\n  BSMs: [ [u1,v1,\"bsm1\"], \u2026, [uk,vk,\"bsmk\"] ], # selected edges forming a noncontractible loop\n  in_nodes: [A_in],                      \n  out_nodes: [B_out],\n  loss_func: \"teleportation_fidelity\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Vary L to study finite-size scaling of p_c.  \n\u2013 Compare the two independent cycles (meridian vs. longitude).  \n\u2013 Extend to random BSM patterns for measurement-induced disorder.  \n\u2013 Explore interplay between lattice geometry (hexagonal, kagome) and percolation.\n\nThis family of experiments concretely merges the PEPS picture (Bell bonds on a torus) with topological order (noncontractible loops), using only static entanglement-swapping networks to reveal a measurement-induced topological transition.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While mapping teleportation fidelity versus the number of Bell\u2010swap measurements around different noncontractible loops on a torus sounds like a nice demonstration of \u201cpercolation,\u201d in practice it\u2019s just a straightforward series of targeted entanglement\u2010swapping paths. You haven\u2019t introduced any new measurement primitive beyond repeated Bell\u2010measurements, nor a genuinely stochastic percolation process\u2014the experiment simply chooses which edges to measure, so there\u2019s no emergent random connectivity to probe. Similar ring\u2010teleportation and dual\u2010path teleportation schemes already exist (e.g. the Zak\u2010phase tomography on a loop, and dual\u2010path Heisenberg dimer teleportation). This is more an exercise in varying the number of swaps than a fundamentally new topological\u2010quantum measurement.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To achieve true novelty, propose a genuinely stochastic or adaptive measurement protocol (e.g. randomly enacted BSMs that self\u2010organize into percolating paths), or invent a new multi\u2010photon projection that unveils a topological phase transition\u2014rather than simply measuring along predetermined loops."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"projected entangled pair state\" and \"topological ordered state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources emit between detectors:\n  edges: (A\u21941), (B\u21942), (C\u21943), (D\u21944).\n  \nAt each of the four vertices (connecting two adjacent virtual bonds) we implement the PEPS projection by performing a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two qubits that meet there. A coincidence detection pattern among A,B,C,D then yields the eigenvalue \u03bb=\u00b11 of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084 (the Wilson-loop operator). By postselecting on any one \u201c\u2212\u201d outcome (up to one BSM error), the two far\u2010end photons remain maximally entangled. This is a direct demonstration of topological error\u2010detection in a photonic network without feed-forward or cluster states.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\nPytheus can optimize four probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (on the four boundary edges) plus two more on the two internal vertical edges. Three BSM modules (each two 50:50 beam splitters + two number\u2010resolving detectors) sit at the three internal vertices. No dynamic control: we postselect on runs with exactly one or zero \u201c\u03a6\u207b\u201d outcomes among the three BSMs. The final two photons at the leftmost and rightmost boundary are measured in the Bell basis to verify entanglement fidelity. All components are static linear optics and photon counting\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nLogical teleportation with topological error detection on a toric\u2010code PEPS patch\n\nExplanation:\nWe encode a distance-3 logical channel using a single 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch. Label the four boundary edges of the square as Left\u2010Top (LT), Left\u2010Bottom (LB), Right\u2010Top (RT), Right\u2010Bottom (RB). We place Bell\u2010pair sources on LT, LB, RT, RB (the \u201cphysical\u201d links) and two additional sources on the two vertical internal edges (connecting top and bottom rows).\n\nAt the three internal vertices (the two upper and lower vertices where a vertical edge meets a horizontal boundary, and the central vertex where the two horizontals meet), we perform Bell\u2010state measurements (BSMs). Each BSM uses static beam splitters and two number\u2010resolving detectors and projects the two incoming virtual qubits onto a Bell state (\u03a6\u207a or \u03a6\u207b).\n\nWe postselect on exactly zero or one \u03a6\u207b outcome among the three BSMs. When at most one \u03a6\u207b occurs, the by\u2010product Pauli can be tracked classically, and the leftmost boundary photon pair (LT,LB) is projected together with the rightmost pair (RT,RB) into a logical Bell state. Thus, any single \u201cerror\u201d (a \u03a6\u207b) does not destroy the end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement\u2014demonstrating topological error detection purely by postselection.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   S1\u2192LT,  S2\u2192LB,  S3\u2192RT,  S4\u2192RB,  S5\u2192(top internal),  S6\u2192(bottom internal)\n BSM modules:\n   BSM1 on (LT,S5) & (S1, boundary-link) top-left vertex  \n   BSM2 on (S5,S6) & (S2,S6) central vertex  \n   BSM3 on (S6,RT) & (S4,RB) bottom-right vertex  \n detectors:\n   Four boundary detectors at LT,LB,RT,RB record the logical ends  \n Postselection:\n   Accept runs with \u22641 \u201c\u03a6\u207b\u201d among {BSM1,BSM2,BSM3}  \n Output:\n   Final two-photon coincidence between left boundary and right boundary \u2192 logical Bell pair\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Logical teleportation through a 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patch with post\u2010selected error detection\",\n  foldername: \"toric_logical_tel\",\n  num_anc: 6,                           # 3 BSMs \u00d7 2 ancilla detectors\n  single_emitters: [],                  # use 6 probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources\n  target_quantum: [\"logical Bell fidelity\"],  \n  in_nodes: [],  \n  out_nodes: [LT,LB,RT,RB],  \n  anc_detectors: [vtx1,vtx2,vtx3],\n  edges: [\n    [S1,LT],[S1,edge1],[S2,LB],[S2,edge2],\n    [S3,RT],[S3,edge3],[S4,RB],[S4,edge4],\n    [S5,edge1],[S5,edge3],[S6,edge2],[S6,edge4]\n  ],\n  BSMs: [\n    [LT,edge1,\"vtx1\"],\n    [edge1,edge2,\"vtx2\"],\n    [edge2,RT,\"vtx3\"]\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"logical_teleportation_fidelity\",  \n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true,\n  heralding_out: null\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Increase the patch to 2\u00d73 or 3\u00d73 to demonstrate distance-d logical teleportation.  \n \u2022 Tile multiple patches to study networked topological channels.  \n \u2022 Vary postselection patterns to explore the code\u2019s distance and failure thresholds.\n\nThis proposal combines PEPS (virtual Bell bonds and projective maps) with topological\u2010code ideas (distance-3 error detection) in a purely linear\u2010optical entanglement\u2010swapping network\u2014novel, scalable, and fully within Pytheus\u2019s static network capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach true novelty, you\u2019ll need to go beyond repeated parity checks\u2014perhaps by demonstrating a non-trivial logical gate or fault-tolerant channel on a toric-code patch (e.g. one that handles both star and plaquette errors, or implements a logical CNOT) in a single static linear-optical network, rather than just teleportation with post-selection.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three PEPS\u2013topological network ideas:\n 1) Wilson\u2010loop stabilizer via PEPS projections (already known).  \n 2) Ring teleportation with emergent phase (similar to Zak\u2010phase proposals).  \n 3) Fault\u2010tolerant logical CNOT on two toric\u2010code PEPS patches via entanglement\u2010swapping (novel static LO network implementing a logical gate and built\u2010in single\u2010error detection).\n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus compatibility:\n \u2022 Idea 3 is new\u2014no prior photonic linear\u2010optics network realizes a logical CNOT in the toric\u2010code PEPS language, nor embeds topological error\u2010detection in a single static circuit.\n \u2022 Pytheus can place Bell\u2010pair sources (probabilistic), single\u2010photon emitters (for inputs), static Bell\u2010state measurements (beam splitters + number\u2010resolving detectors), and detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback required.\n\nStep 3: Select idea 3.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\nThis is the first proposal for a purely linear-optical network that encodes two photonic qubits into adjacent 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patches, performs a logical CNOT by entanglement\u2010swapping across the shared edge, and post-selectively detects any single \u201cerror\u201d via the patch\u2019s topological structure. No cluster states or feed\u2010forward.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\nWe use 2 single-photon emitters (inputs), 7 Bell-pair sources (5 boundary edges + 2 internal links), 6 static BSM modules (each with 2 ancilla detectors), and 2 output detectors. Postselecting trivial by\u2010product outcomes yields the logical CNOT on the two output photons. All components are static probabilistic sources, linear optics, and photon counting\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nFault-Tolerant Logical CNOT via Toric-Code PEPS Entanglement-Swapping\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange two 2\u00d72 toric-code PEPS patches A (left) and B (right) sharing one internal edge. Each PEPS virtual bond is a Bell pair; projections are done by Bell-state measurements (BSMs) at the vertices.\n\n\u2022 Inputs: two single-photon emitters inject qubits |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9,|\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 on the left boundary edges of patches A and B.\n\u2022 Bell-pair sources on the remaining 5 boundary edges (3 in A, 2 in B) and on the 2 internal links (one vertical in A, one vertical in B).\n\u2022 BSM modules at the 6 internal vertices (static 50:50 beam splitters + two number-resolving detectors each) enact the PEPS projections.\n\u2022 Outputs: two photons emerge at the right boundary edges of A and B, carrying the logical qubits after a CNOT: |x,y\u27e9\u2192|x,x\u2295y\u27e9.\n\u2022 Postselection: accept runs where all six BSMs yield trivial \u201c\u03a6\u207a\u201d except at most one \u201c\u03a6\u207b\u201d (the toric code\u2019s single-error tolerance). Classical by-product corrections are tracked offline.\n\u2022 Verification: measure a Bell-fidelity between the two output photons in the computational basis, confirming the CNOT action.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters:  E1\u2192A_left, E2\u2192B_left  \n sources:   S1,S2,S3 on A boundary; S4,S5 on B boundary; S6,S7 on internal links  \n BSMs:      M1\u2026M6 at the six vertices  \n detectors: D1\u2192A_right, D2\u2192B_right; ancilla detectors at M1\u2026M6  \n\nPytheus\u2010config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Logical CNOT via two adjacent 2\u00d72 toric\u2010code PEPS patches\",\n  foldername: \"toric_peps_logical_cnot\",\n  single_emitters: [E1,E2],          # LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to fuse \u201cprojected entangled pair state\u201d and \u201ctopological ordered state\u201d into a purely network-based experiment (no new state generation, only entanglement swapping/teleportation).\n 1) Static measurement of a toric-code plaquette via Bell-swap projections (already seen in parity-check proposals).  \n 2) Teleportation on a 1D PEPS ring with emergent topological phase (too similar to Zak-phase tomography).  \n 3) Measurement-induced topological percolation on a PEPS network: use a 2D torus (PEPS of Bell bonds) and selective Bell-measurements (entanglement swapping) to drive non-contractible entanglement paths; map out a percolation-like threshold for long-range teleportation across two non-homotopic loops.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & obstacles\n\u2022 Idea 3 is novel: no prior experiment uses Bell-pair lattices + swapping to explore topologically nontrivial entanglement percolation.  \n\u2022 Pytheus can place probabilistic Bell sources on graph edges, static BSM modules (beam splitters + number-resolving detectors) at chosen vertices, and optimize for high teleportation fidelity between two distant nodes.\n\nStep 3: Pick idea 3.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it turns a 2D PEPS (Bell-pair lattice) into a \u201cmeasurement-induced topological network,\u201d where one witnesses the emergence of long-range entangled channels along noncontractible loops on a torus. No existing photonic linear-optics experiment has mapped out such a topological percolation/phase transition via entanglement swapping.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because:\n \u2022 All resources are probabilistic Bell-pair sources and static Bell-state measurements\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n \u2022 The target is simply \u201cmaximally entangle node A to node B across a given homotopy class,\u201d which Pytheus can optimize via its linear-optics graph search.  \n \u2022 The configuration can be varied in size (3\u00d73, 4\u00d74, \u2026) and in pattern of swaps, providing a family of experiments.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nMeasurement-Induced Topological Percolation in a Bell-Pair Torus\n\nExplanation:\nWe take an L\u00d7L toroidal lattice of photonic nodes. Each edge carries a Bell pair from a probabilistic source. Two opposite nodes, A and B, are chosen as \u201cboundaries\u201d between which we wish to teleport an unknown qubit. To do so, we perform Bell-state measurements (BSMs) on a subset of edges that forms a path on the dual lattice. When that path winds around a noncontractible cycle of the torus, A and B become entangled via entanglement swapping along that loop.\n\nBy varying which edges are measured (and how many), one can map out a \u201cpercolation threshold\u201d p_c: the minimum density of BSMs required to achieve high-fidelity teleportation around each independent cycle. Pytheus\u2019s job is to find, for each loop (say the \u201cmeridional\u201d and \u201clongitudinal\u201d directions), the optimal static LO network (choice of beam splitters and detectors) that maximizes teleportation fidelity between A and B using only k BSMs. Repeating for k=1\u2026K traces out the onset of topological connectivity.\n\nVisualization (for L=3):\n\u2013 Emitters/sources: Bell pairs on all 18 edges of a 3\u00d73 torus (edges wrap around).  \n\u2013 BSM modules: placed on k selected edges forming a continuous loop from A back to B along one homotopy class; each BSM is a 50:50 beam splitter + two number-resolving detectors.  \n\u2013 Input qubit: encoded on one half of the Bell pair at node A.  \n\u2013 Output qubit: recovered on the other half at node B after all k BSMs.  \n\u2013 Postselection: keep runs where every BSM clicks once. Measure fidelity of teleportation from A\u2192B.\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Topological percolation on a 3\u00d73 Bell-pair torus\",\n  foldername: \"torus_percolation_3\",\n  single_emitters: [],                    \n  num_anc: 2*k,                           # two ancilla detectors per BSM \u00d7 k swaps\n  anc_detectors: [\"bsm1\",\u2026,\"bsmk\"],\n  edges: [ all 18 Bell-pair source connections ],\n  BSMs: [ [u1,v1,\"bsm1\"], \u2026, [uk,vk,\"bsmk\"] ], # selected edges forming a noncontractible loop\n  in_nodes: [A_in],                      \n  out_nodes: [B_out],\n  loss_func: \"teleportation_fidelity\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Vary L to study finite-size scaling of p_c.  \n\u2013 Compare the two independent cycles (meridian vs. longitude).  \n\u2013 Extend to random BSM patterns for measurement-induced disorder.  \n\u2013 Explore interplay between lattice geometry (hexagonal, kagome) and percolation.\n\nThis family of experiments concretely merges the PEPS picture (Bell bonds on a torus) with topological order (noncontractible loops), using only static entanglement-swapping networks to reveal a measurement-induced topological transition.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve true novelty, propose a genuinely stochastic or adaptive measurement protocol (e.g. randomly enacted BSMs that self\u2010organize into percolating paths), or invent a new multi\u2010photon projection that unveils a topological phase transition\u2014rather than simply measuring along predetermined loops.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible network experiments merging PEPS + topological order (focusing on entanglement swapping/teleportation rather than state generation):\n 1) Plaquette\u2010stabilizer measurement via PEPS projections (already known).  \n 2) Teleportation loops on a torus to read out anyonic braiding (too close to Zak\u2010phase tomography).  \n 3) Measurement-based implementation of a logical Pauli operator (e.g. Z) on a qubit encoded in a 2\u00d72 toric-code PEPS patch via entanglement-swapping network.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & Pytheus\u2010obstacles for (3):\n \u2022 Novelty: No prior photonic network has used a toric-code PEPS and only Bell-pair sources + BSMs to enact a logical Z on a teleported qubit in a single static circuit.  \n \u2022 Feasibility: Pytheus can handle probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources on edges, single\u2010photon emitter for the input, static Bell-state measurements (50:50 beam splitters + number\u2010resolving detectors) for injection, patch projection, loop measurement, and extraction. No feedback, no cavities.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty\nThis protocol enacts the logical Z operator of the toric\u2010code on an unknown qubit by routing it through a 2\u00d72 PEPS patch: you teleport the qubit in, perform a Bell-swap around the noncontractible cycle to apply Z, then teleport out. This is a purely network-based, linear-optics implementation of a topologically protected logical gate\u2014no cluster states, no feed-forward.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility\nPytheus can optimize five Bell-pair sources (four for the PEPS bonds + one for teleportation injection or extraction), two single\u2010photon emitters (one for the input, one for the output if desired), four static BSM modules at the patch vertices, and two extra BSMs for teleportation in/out. All are static linear-optical elements and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The loss function can be a gate\u2010fidelity to Z.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Z Gate on a Toric-Code PEPS Patch\n\nExplanation:\nWe build a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code PEPS patch whose four virtual bonds are Bell pairs. We implement a measurement-based logical Z on an unknown photonic qubit by:\n1) Teleportation injection: perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM\u2080) between the input qubit (from a single-photon emitter E_in) and one half of a Bell pair (source S_in).  \n2) PEPS projection: at each of the four vertices of the patch, perform a static BSM (M1\u2026M4) on the two virtual qubits meeting there. This projects the four remaining halves onto the toric-code map.  \n3) Loop measurement (logical Z): perform a BSM_L on the two virtual qubits along one noncontractible cycle of the patch. This step implements the logical Z on the encoded qubit.  \n4) Teleportation extraction: perform a final BSM\u2093 between the logical output bond and a fresh Bell pair (source S_out), routing the now-Z-rotated qubit to the detection output.\n\nPostselect on all BSM outcomes projecting onto |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 (trivial by-products). The overall transformation from E_in\u2192Detector_Out is the Pauli Z gate: |0\u27e9\u2192|0\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192\u2212|1\u27e9.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   E_in \u2192 input qubit  \n   S_in \u2192 injection Bell pair  \n   S1\u2026S4 \u2192 PEPS bonds on the four edges  \n   S_out \u2192 extraction Bell pair  \n BSMs:\n   BSM\u2080 on (E_in, S_in)  \n   M1 on (S1_half, S2_half)  \n   M2 on (S2_other, S3_half)  \n   M3 on (S3_other, S4_half)  \n   M4 on (S4_other, S1_other)  \n   BSM_L on the two halves lying along the chosen noncontractible loop  \n   BSM\u2093 on (loop-output, S_out_half)  \n detectors:\n   Detector_Out records the final qubit  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Logical Z via entanglement-swapping on a 2\u00d72 toric-code PEPS patch\",\n  foldername: \"toric_peps_logical_Z\",\n  single_emitters: [E_in],        \n  num_anc: 12,                    # 6 BSMs \u00d7 2 ancilla detectors each\n  anc_detectors: [BSM0,M1,M2,M3,M4,BSM_L,BSM_x],\n  edges: [\n    [S_in, inj1],[S_in, inj2],\n    [S1, v1],[S1, v2],[S2, v2],[S2, v3],\n    [S3, v3],[S3, v4],[S4, v4],[S4, v1],\n    [S_out, out1],[S_out, out2]\n  ],\n  BSMs: [\n    [E_in, inj1, \"BSM0\"],\n    [v1, v2, \"M1\"],[v2, v3, \"M2\"],[v3, v4, \"M3\"],[v4, v1, \"M4\"],\n    [loop_q1, loop_q2, \"BSM_L\"],\n    [loop_out, out1, \"BSM_x\"]\n  ],\n  out_nodes: [out2],                   \n  loss_func: \"gate_fidelity_Z\",     \n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  thresholds: [0.9],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Implement logical X by measuring the orthogonal noncontractible loop.  \n \u2022 Chain patches to build a full logical Clifford group without feed-forward.  \n \u2022 Study robustness by allowing one \u201c\u03a6\u207b\u201d outcome (error detection) using toric-code redundancy.  \n\nThis experiment fuses PEPS (virtual Bell bonds), topological order (toric-code logical operators), and entanglement-swapping teleportation to realize a measurement-based logical gate in a purely linear-optical network\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010network capabilities."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. Each adjacent pair (i,i+1 mod N) is connected by a Bell\u2010pair source. Node 0 holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 that Alice wishes to teleport to node k (e.g. k=N/2). To do so, one performs standard Bell\u2010state measurements (BSM) at the intermediate nodes along two disjoint paths around the ring\u2014nodes 1,\u2026,k\u22121 and nodes N\u22121,\u2026,k+1. Concretely for N=4, connect 0\u20131,1\u20132,2\u20133,3\u20130; perform BSMs at nodes 1 and 3. The remaining photon at node 2 is projected onto |\u03c8\u27e9 up to Pauli corrections. For odd N the cycle\u2019s global phase contributes a detectable sign (a Z\u2010phase on the teleported qubit), directly reflecting the periodic PEPS topology.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/sources: photons from edges 2\u20133 and 3\u20130, measures in Bell basis (2 ancilla detectors)\noutput node: detector at node 2 yields teleported |\u03c8\u27e9\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{  \n  description: In the PEPS language each of the four virtual bonds is a Bell pair. Concretely, label the four physical \u201cvirtual\u201d qubits 1,2,3,4 at the midpoints of the square\u2019s edges. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources emit between detectors:\n  edges: (A\u21941), (B\u21942), (C\u21943), (D\u21944).\n  \nAt each of the four vertices (connecting two adjacent virtual bonds) we implement the PEPS projection by performing a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two qubits that meet there. These are static 50:50 beam splitters + number-resolving detectors (2 per vertex). We postselect only the \u201c|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u201d outcome at every vertex.\n\nAfter these four entanglement\u2010swapping projections, the remaining four photons at A,B,C,D carry exactly the plaquette degree of freedom of the toric code. A coincidence detection pattern among A,B,C,D then yields the eigenvalue \u03bb=\u00b11 of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084 (the Wilson-loop operator). By repeating and tallying \u00b1 outcomes, one directly measures the topological stabilizer.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters:  \n   Bell-pair sources \u2192 virtual-bond qubits: [1][2][3][4]  \n projection network:  \n   BSM1 on (1,2) at top-left vertex,  \n   BSM2 on (2,3) at top-right,  \n   BSM3 on (3,4) bottom-right,  \n   BSM4 on (4,1) bottom-left  \n detectors:  \n   A, B, C, D record the four edge photons  \n postselect: all four BSMs yield |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 outcome  \n output: fourfold coincidence at A,B,C,D \u2192 measurement of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Toric-code plaquette (Wilson-loop) analyzer via PEPS projections\",\n  foldername: \"toric_plaquette_analyzer\",\n  num_anc: 8,                    # We place Bell\u2010pair sources on LT, LB, RT, RB (the \u201cphysical\u201d links) and two additional sources on the two vertical internal edges (connecting top and bottom rows).\n\nAt the three internal vertices (the two upper and lower vertices where a vertical edge meets a horizontal boundary, and the central vertex where the two horizontals meet), we perform Bell\u2010state measurements (BSMs).
