This representation ensures that no certain spin configurations occur over three consecutive sites in $\\ket{\\psi_{\\beta}}$.\n\n\\begin{figure}\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.25\\textwidth]{graph_onsager6.pdf} \\hspace{-4mm}\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.23\\textwidth]{graph_onsager8.pdf}\n \\caption {The associated graphs for the Onsager's scar in a system with six~(left panel) and eight~(right) qubits. Here we set $\\beta=1/\\sqrt{2}$.}\n\t\\label{fig:onsager}\n\\end{figure}\n\nFig.~\\ref{fig:onsager} displays the graph associated with the Onsager's scar in a system with six and eight spins, with $\\beta=1/\\sqrt{2}$. Up to normalization, the states read \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/onsager6]{experimentcounter}\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/onsager8]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi_{\\beta}^{(6)}} &= +2(\\ket{000011} -\\ket{000110} +\\ket{001100}   \\notag \\\\\n        &+ \\ket{110000} -\\ket{011000} -\\ket{100001})  \\notag \\\\\n        &+\\ket{011110} +\\ket{001111} +\\ket{100111}    \\notag \\\\\n        &-\\ket{101101} -\\ket{011011} +\\ket{110011}   \\notag \\\\\n        & - \\ket{110110} +\\ket{111001} +\\ket{111100}  \\notag \\\\\n        &+ 4\\ket{000000} ,\n\\end{align}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi_{\\beta}^{(8)}} =& \n    8\\ket{00000000}+4(\\ket{00000011}-\\ket{00000110}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+\\ket{00001100}-\\ket{00011000}+\\ket{00110000}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &-\\ket{01100000}+\\ket{11000000}-\\ket{10000001})\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+2(\\ket{00001111}-\\ket{00011011}+\\ket{00011110}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+\\ket{00110011}-\\ket{00110110}+\\ket{00111100}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &-\\ket{01100011}+\\ket{01100110}-\\ket{01101100}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+\\ket{01111000}+\\ket{10000111}-\\ket{10001101}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+\\ket{10011001}-\\ket{10110001}+\\ket{11000011}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &-\\ket{11000110}+\\ket{11001100}-\\ket{11011000}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+\\ket{11100001}+\\ket{11110000})+\\ket{00111111}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+\\ket{10110111}-\\ket{10111101}-\\ket{01101111}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &-\\ket{10011111}+\\ket{11001111}-\\ket{11011011}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+\\ket{11011110}+\\ket{01111011}-\\ket{01111110}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &-\\ket{11100111}+\\ket{11101101}+\\ket{11110011}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &-\\ket{11110110}-\\ket{11111001}+\\ket{11111100}\\nonumber \\\\\n    &+\\ket{11111111}.   \n\\end{align}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Scars in the PXP Model --}\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_pxp6.pdf}\\hspace{-3mm}\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_pxp8.pdf}\n \\caption {The graphs associated with the ground state of the PXP model with six~(left panel) and eight~(right) particles.}\n\t\\label{fig:PXP}\n\\end{figure}\nAnother platform where quantum scars emerge is in the $PXP$ model. This model on a chain with $L$ sites and with the periodic boundary condition is~\\cite{Lin2019}\n\\begin{align}\n    {\\cal H} = \\sum_{i} P_{i-1} X_{i} P_{i+1} + P_{L} X_{1} P_{2} + P_{L-1} X_{L} P_{1},\n\\end{align}\nwhere $P=\\ket{0}\\bra{0}$ and $X=\\ket{0}\\bra{1}+\\ket{1}\\bra{0}$. One of the ground states of this model in the matrix product representation yields\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\text{PXP}} = \\sum_{\\{ \\sigma \\}}\n    \\tr [\nB^{\\sigma_{1}} C^{\\sigma_{2}}\n\\ldots\nB^{\\sigma_{L-1}} C^{\\sigma_{L-1}}\n    ]\n    \\ket{\\sigma_{1} \\sigma_{2}  \\ldots \\sigma_{L}},\n\\end{align}\nwhere\n\\begin{align}\n    B^{0} &= \n    \\begin{pmatrix}\n         1 & 0 & 0 \\\\\n         0 & 1 & 0\n    \\end{pmatrix}\n    ,\\quad \n   B^{1} = \\sqrt{2} \n   \\begin{pmatrix}\n       0 & 0 & 0 \\\\\n       1 & 0 & 1\n   \\end{pmatrix}\n   ,\\\\\n   C^{0} &=\n   \\begin{pmatrix}\n       0 & -1 \\\\\n       1 & 0 \\\\\n       0 & 0\n   \\end{pmatrix}\n   ,\\quad \n   C^{1} = \\sqrt{2} \n   \\begin{pmatrix}\n       1 & 0 \\\\\n       0 & 0 \\\\\n       -1 & 0\n   \\end{pmatrix}.\n\\end{align}\nFig.~\\ref{fig:PXP} displays the graph associated with the ground state of the PXP model with six and eight particles. Up to normalization, these states read \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/pxp6]{experimentcounter} \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/pxp8]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\text{PXP6}} &= \\ket{000000} - \\ket{000010} \\notag\\\\\n     &- \\ket{101000} - \\ket{100000} \\notag\\\\\n    &+ \\ket{101010}  - 2\\ket{010100}  \\notag\\\\\n    &+ \\sqrt{2}(\\ket{100100} + \\ket{010000}) ,\n\\end{align}\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\text{PXP8}} &= \\ket{00000000} + \\ket{00001000} \\notag \\\\\n & + \\ket{10000000} + \\ket{10101010} \\notag \\\\\n & -\\ket{00001010} -\\ket{10000010} \\notag \\\\\n & -\\ket{10100000} -\\ket{10101000} \\notag \\\\\n & -2( \\ket{01010000}+\\ket{10010100}) \\notag \\\\\n & + \\sqrt{2}(\\ket{01000010} - \\ket{00000100} \\notag \\\\\n & + \\ket{10010000} - \\ket{01000000}\\notag \\\\\n & + \\ket{10100100} + 2\\ket{01010100} ).\n\\end{align}\n\n\n\n\n\n\\subsection{Quantum Communication}\\label{experiments:qcommunication}\nQuantum communication refers to communication protocols that involve the transfer of quantum states. Machine learning has been previously employed for the artificial discovery of quantum communication schemes \\cite{wallnofer2020machine}.\n\n\n\nThe first experimental realization of entanglement swapping was presented as a way of entangling two photons that never interacted \\cite{pan1998experimental}. In this section we show graphs corresponding to experiments that create entanglement between two parties  (each party with single or multiple photons) without interaction between the parties. Entanglement swapping has a strong connection to other quantum communication tasks, e.g.\\ teleportation. This opens the door to use \\pytheus for discovering related quantum information protocols.\n\n\\paragraph{Entangling Two Photons that Never Interacted without Bell Pairs --}\nRespecting the constraints that are placed on two particles that do not interact (presented in section \\ref{sec:qcommunication}) we show a graph that entangles two photons from independent sources in Fig.~\\ref{fig:entswap} . The corresponding setup constructed by path identity does not require the initial creation of entangled Bell pairs \\numbering{experimentcounter}. \n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n\\centering\n\\includegraphics[width=0.48\\textwidth]{entswap.png}\n\\caption {Entanglement between two qubits without a common source. Because the vertices a and d have no connection in the graph, each of the corresponding photons is created in one of two disjoint subsystems (green boxes).}\n\\label{fig:entswap}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Multiparticle Entanglement Swapping --}\nPerforming simultaneous entanglement swapping on multiple pairs of particles is one of the key players in achieving resource-efficient quantum communication. Entanglement swapping between two qubits requires two additional particles for a Bell state measurement. Performing this swapping experiment in parallel for $n$ qubit pairs would require $2n$ additional photons. We prompted \\pytheus to find experiments that beat this naive baseline. With this, we found a three-qubit entanglement swapping experiment (Fig.~\\ref{fig:mmultiswap}), which produces the state \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Communication/3pES]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\Phi^+}_{03}\\otimes\\ket{\\Phi^+}_{14}\\otimes\\ket{\\Phi^+}_{25},\n\\end{align}\nwhere the photons $0,1,2$ are separated from $3,4,5$. This experiment requires four additional particles instead of the six particles necessary for the parallel case described above.\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\\centering\n\\subfloat[Three qubit ES]{\\includegraphics[width=0.22\\textwidth]{graph_3pES_boosted.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\\subfloat[Outline of Experiment]{\\includegraphics[width=0.26\\textwidth]{alicebob.png}}\n\\caption{\\textbf{Entanglement swapping of 3 Bell pairs measuring only 4 photons.}  Left: abstract graph for multi-particle entanglement swapping. Right: outline of a multi-particle Entanglement swapping experiment. Alice and Bob each receive three particles from the two independent sources 1 and 2 (each a collection of SPDC crystals). When Charlie measures a coincidence in all four detectors Alice and Bob share three Bell pairs (0\\&3, 1\\&4, 2\\&5) without them having interacted. This is possible due to a superposition of events where Charlie either receives three photons from Alice and one photon from Bob or one photon from Alice and three photons from Bob.}\n\\label{fig:mmultiswap}\n\\end{figure}\n\nSimilarly, entanglement swapping between a pair of qutrits requires four ancillary particles. We found that \"performing entanglement swapping for two pairs of qutrits could also beat the naive baseline by only requiring six ancillas instead of eight, in total, to produce \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Communication/2pES_3d]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\Phi^+}^{3d}_{02}\\otimes\\ket{\\Phi^+}^{3d}_{13},\n\\end{align}\nwhere the photons $0,1$ are separated from $2,3$, and $\\ket{\\Phi^+}^{3d}$ is the first three-dimensional Bell state.\n\n\\paragraph{Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources}\nIt is also possible to use single-photon sources for entanglement swapping \\cite{basset2019entanglement,troiani2014entanglement,zopf2019entanglement}. In Fig.~\\ref{fig:entanglementswapping}, we show a graph \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Communication/ES3d_sp]{experimentcounter} for a higher-dimensional case, performing three-dimensional entanglement swapping with single photon sources. In total, six single photon sources are necessary. \n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\\centering\n\\subfloat[2 qutrit ES]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_2pES_3d.pdf}}\\!\\!\n \\subfloat[2 qutrit ES (s.p.s)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_ES3d_sp.pdf}}\n\\caption {Graphs for entanglement swapping experiments.}\n\\label{fig:entanglementswapping}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\subsection{Quantum Measurements}\\label{exp:quantum_measurements}\nAn important tool in quantum information is multi-particle measurements such as the Bell state measurement \\cite{weinfurter1994experimental} or the GHZ analyzer \\cite{ghzanalyzer}. Here we present a wider range of measurements that \\pytheus has discovered. Many others, such as POVM (positive operator-valued measure) or their symmetric, informationally complete special case (SIC-POVMs) could be additional targets for future research, given their exceptional importance for quantum information tasks \\cite{bergou2010discrimination,bent2015experimental} as well as their connection to exciting number theoretical questions \\cite{caves2002unknown}.\n\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Analyzers}\nHere, we use the word \\textit{analyzer} to refer to experimental setups that confirm a collection of photons to be in a particular state. Their formulation in terms of graphs is described in \\ref{sec:measurements}. The two-dimensional GHZ analyzer realized in Ref.~\\cite{ghzanalyzer} can be extended towards higher dimensions, giving the 3d GHZ analyzer \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Measurements/ghz_analyzer_3d]{experimentcounter} and the 4d GHZ analyzer \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/blob/main/pytheus/graphs/Measurements/ghz_analyzer_4d]{experimentcounter}. Further, we show analyzers for the W state \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Measurements/W_measurement]{experimentcounter}, the Higuchi-Sudbery state (shown in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:HSstate}) \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Measurements/HS_measurement]{experimentcounter} and the Yeo-Chua state (shown in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:YC}) \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Measurements/YC_measurement]{experimentcounter} in Fig.~\\ref{fig:analyzers}.\n\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[GHZ analyzer 3d]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_ghz_analyzer_3d.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/Measurements/ghz_analyzer_3d.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[GHZ analyzer 4d]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_ghz_analyzer_4d.pdf}}\\\\%{Graphs/Measurements/analyzer_ghz_4d.pdf}}\\\\\n     \\subfloat[Higuchi-Sudbery analyzer]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_HS_measurement_v2.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/Measurements/analyzer_HS.pdf}}\\!\\!\n     \\subfloat[W analyzer]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_W_measurement.pdf}}\\\\%{Graphs/Measurements/anaylzer_w.pdf}}\n     \\subfloat[Yeo-Chua analyzer]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_YC_measurement.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for analyzers. When all detectors click, the incoming photons were in the corresponding state.}\n\t\\label{fig:analyzers}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Mean King's Problem}\\label{subsubsec:meanking}\n\nIn 1987, L. Vaidman, Y. Akaronov, and D. Z. Albert \\cite{vaidman1987} devised an interesting quantum communication task that can be solved only with quantum resources. Later referred to as the Mean King's Problem (MKP), it involves two parties. Alice, who sends a quantum state which she created to another party -- the Mean King. The Mean King then performs a projective measurement on the state in a basis of his choice out of a collection of mutually unbiased bases (MUBs). Alice is then allowed to perform one more measurement, after which the King declares his measurement basis and Alice must correctly guess his result. Should Alice guess incorrectly even once, she will suffer a cruel fate, for the Mean King is exceptionally intolerant of poor guesses. This task has applications in  quantum key distribution, wherein even the slightest discrepancy between the shared secret key of Alice and Bob implicates (in principle) the presence of an eavesdropper.  \n\nOver the years, various generalizations to the initial solution, proposed in the original paper \\cite{vaidman1987}, have been introduced. Here, we employ a generalization proposed by Hayashi, Horibe, and Hashimoto \\cite{hayashi2005} for quantum states of dimension $D$ which is a prime power. This solution proposes that Alice first prepares a maximally entangled, two-photon state $\\ket{\\psi_o}$ and sends one of her photons to the Mean King.  After the King makes a projective measurement in one of the $(D+1)$ MUBs, Alice retrieves her photon and performs a measurement in the basis of states credited to Vaidman, Akaronov, and Albert (VAA states). There are $D^2$ VAA states in all. For $D=2$, the first VAA state can be written as \n \\begin{align}\n        \\ket{\\phi_1} &= \\frac{1}{2} (\\sqrt{2}\\ket{00} + e^{-i\\frac{\\pi}{4}}\\ket{01} + e^{i\\frac{\\pi} {4}}\\ket{10})\n        %\\ket{\\phi_2} &= \\frac{1}{2} (\\sqrt{2}\\ket{00} + e^{-i\\frac{\\pi}{4}}\\ket{01} - e^{i\\frac{\\pi} {4}}\\ket{10}), \\\\\n       % \\ket{\\phi_3} &= \\frac{1}{2}(\\sqrt{2} \\ket{11} + e^{i\\frac{\\pi}{4}}\\ket{01} + e^{-i\\frac{\\pi}{4}}\\ket{10}), \\\\\n       % \\ket{\\phi_4} &= \\frac{1}{2}(\\sqrt{2} \\ket{11} - e^{i\\frac{\\pi}{4}}\\ket{01} + e^{-i\\frac{\\pi}{4}}\\ket{10}).\n\\end{align}\nFor $D=3$, the third VAA state can be written as \n \\begin{align}\n        %\\ket{\\phi_1} &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{00} + \\ket{01} + \\ket{10}), \\\\\n        %\\ket{\\phi_2} &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{00} + \\alpha(\\ket{01} + \\ket{10} + \\ket{12} + \\ket{21})\\\\ \\nonumber\n        %&+ \\beta\\ket{20} + \\gamma\\ket{02}), \\\\\n        \\ket{\\phi_3} &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{00} + \\alpha(\\ket{02} + \\ket{10} + \\ket{01} + \\ket{20}) \\\\ \\nonumber\n        &+ \\beta(\\ket{12}) + \\gamma(\\ket{21})) \n        %\\ket{\\phi_4} &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{11} + \\beta(\\ket{12} + \\ket{20}) + \\gamma(\\ket{02} + \\ket{21}) \\\\ \\nonumber\n        %&+ \\epsilon(\\ket{01}) + \\nu(\\ket{10})),\n        %\\end{align}\n        %\\begin{align}\n        %\\ket{\\phi_5} &=  \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{11} + \\omega\\ket{02} + \\omega^{*}\\ket{20}),\\\\\n        %\\ket{\\phi_6} &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{11} + \\alpha(\\ket{12} + \\ket{21}) + \\nu(\\ket{01} + \\ket{20})\\\\ \\nonumber\n        %&+ \\epsilon(\\ket{02} + \\ket{10})), \\\\\n       % \\ket{\\phi_7} &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{22} + \\beta(\\ket{01} + \\ket{10}) + \\gamma(\\ket{12} + \\ket{21})\\\\ \\nonumber \n        %&+ \\epsilon\\ket{20} + \\nu\\ket{02}), \\\\\n      %  \\ket{\\phi_8} &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{22} + \\alpha(\\ket{01} + \\ket{10}) + \\epsilon(\\ket{12} + \\ket{21})\\\\ \\nonumber &+ \\nu(\\ket{20} + \\ket{02})), \\\\\n       %\\ket{\\phi_9} &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} (\\ket{12} + \\omega\\ket{21} + \\omega^{*}\\ket{22}),\n      \\end{align}\nwhere $\\omega=e^{-i 2\\pi/3}$, $\\alpha=(\\omega^2 + 2\\omega)/3$, $\\beta=(\\omega^2 + 2)/3$, and $\\gamma=(\\omega + 2)/3$, \n\n%$\\epsilon=(1 + 2\\omega)/3$, and $\\nu=(2\\omega^2 +1)/3$.\n%\\begin{align}\n%\\omega &= e^{-i\\frac{2\\pi}{3}} & \\nonumber\n%\\alpha &= \\frac{\\omega^2 + 2\\omega}{3}\\\\ \\nonumber\n%\\beta &= \\frac{\\omega^2 + 2}{3} &\n%\\gamma &= \\frac{\\omega + 2}{3} \\\\ \\nonumber\n%\\epsilon &= \\frac{1 + 2\\omega}{3} &\n%\\nu &= \\frac{2\\omega^2 +1}{3} \\nonumber\n%\\end{align}\n%\\begin{equation}\n%    \\ket{\\phi_k} =  -\\ket{\\psi_{o}} + \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{D}}\\sum_{m=0}^{D}   \\ket{m_{f_{k}(m)}\\bar{m_{f_{k}(m)}}}.\n%\\end{equation}\n%Where $m=0,1...D$ denotes the $m^{th}$ basis, $k=0,1...D^2$, $f_{k}(m)$ is a function that maps to an eigenstate of basis m. It is defined as the constructing function for a set of $D+1$ orthogonal Latin squares: \n%\\begin{equation}\n%    f_{k}(m)= \\begin{cases}\n%    j \\ominus mi  & m=0,1,...,D-1 \\\\\n%    i   & m=D\n%    \\end{cases}\n%\\end{equation}\n%Where we refer to the $(i,j)$th element in the Latin square, and $k$ is decomposed as $k=D*j + i$. Note that addition and multiplication are defined according to the rules of the finite field $F(D)$.\n\n\nExperimentally realizing Alice's measurement in this basis is non-trivial. Setups that recreate the two-dimensional VAA measurement using two qubits encoded in a single photon  \\cite{oliver2003,Englert2001} and that realize extensions to the Mean King's problem \\cite{chengQiuHu2020} have been proposed; but the original solution to the Mean King's Problem involves two photons, to which no experimental realization has been proposed for any prime-power $D$. Here we provide examples discovered by \\pytheus for select prime-dimensional cases.  \n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[MKP (2d)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_MKP_2d.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[MKP (3d)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_MKP_3d.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs realizing the VAA state measurement for the MKP in the 2-dimensional case and 3-dimensional case.}\n\t\\label{fig:mkp}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\paragraph{Two-dimensional Case --} The left side of Fig.~\\ref{fig:mkp} shows the graph of Alice's measurement in the VAA basis \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Measurements/MKP_2d]{experimentcounter}. This graph was found with \\pytheus by optimizing for the VAA state projection into $\\ket{\\phi_{1}}$. Surprisingly however, during the translation of the graph to an optical setup, we found that several other VAA states can be projected with the same setup, by adding detectors at unused beam splitter ports. Several of the remaining VAA states can then be distinguished by the set of possible simultaneous two-detector click events that they each trigger. Since any result of the Mean King's measurement can be expressed in terms of a superposition of VAA states, Alice is able to guess the result by performing the measurement of her input state in the VAA basis and guessing the state that can be expressed in terms of Alice's measurement result. This procedure works regardless of the Mean King's choice of MUB in his measurement.   %The possible two-detector click events upon sending each VAA state to this basis are as follows. \n%\\begin{align*}\n%    \\ket{\\phi_0}  & \\rightarrow & c_0d_0, c_0e_0, c_0f_0, c_0g_0, d_0f_0,d_0g_0, e_0f_0, e_0g_0, f_0g_0 ,\\\\\n%    \\ket{\\phi_1} & \\rightarrow & c_0d_0, c_0e_0, c_0f_0, c_0g_0, d_0f_0, d_0g_0, e_0f_0, e_0g_0, f_0g_0 , \\\\\n%    \\ket{\\phi_2} & \\rightarrow & c_0d_0, c_0e_0, e_0f_0, d_0f_0, d_0g_0, e_0f_0, e_0g_0  ,\\\\\n%     \\ket{\\phi_3} & \\rightarrow & c_0d_0, c_0e_0, c_0f_0, d_0f_0, e_0f_0, e_0g_0,f_0g_0,\n%\\end{align*}\n%Where we note that the two-detector event $c_0g_0$ does not occur when we send $\\ket{\\phi_2}$ or $\\ket{\\phi_3}$.\n\n%Alice can then retrodict the King's measurement on her maximally entangled state $\\ket{\\psi_0}$ using the following protocol: If the King's measuring basis corresponds to m=0, Alice concludes that the king has measured $\\ket{11}=\\ket{\\phi_2} + \\ket{\\phi_3}$ if the detectors $c$ and $g$ do not trigger simultaneously. Otherwise, she must conclude that the king has measured $\\ket{00} = \\ket{\\phi_0} + \\ket{\\phi_1}$.  If the king chooses $m=1$ as his measurement basis, Alice concludes that the King has measured $\\ket{1_{1}\\bar{1_{1}}} = \\ket{\\phi_1} + \\ket{\\phi_2}$ provided that the detector $g$ triggers simultaneously with $d$ but never with $c$. If it is detector $f$ that triggers instead of $d$, then Alice instead concludes that $\\ket{1_{0}\\bar{1_0}} = \\ket{\\phi_0} + \\ket{\\phi_3}$ was measured (Alice would need to throw away events indicating that $\\ket{\\phi_0}$ or $\\ket{\\phi_1}$ was measured. In the case of $m=2$, Alice can follow a similar procedure to conclude that the King has measured $\\ket{2_0\\bar{2_0}} =  \\ket{\\phi_0} + \\ket{\\phi_2}$ or $\\ket{2_1\\bar{2_1}} =  \\ket{\\phi_1} + \\ket{\\phi_3}$.%\n\n\\paragraph{Three-Dimensional Case --}\nThe right-hand side of Fig. ~\\ref{fig:mkp} shows the graph for the projection of the state into the one of the three-dimensional VAA states $\\ket{\\phi_{3}}$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Measurements/MKP_3d]{experimentcounter}. As with the two-dimensional case, we add again detectors at the empty port of beam splitters and find that we can distinguish between more three of the nine states without any additional modifications. After post-selection, Alice has a guaranteed chance to correctly guess the Mean King's measurement result so long as the King does not choose the second MUB for his measurement. Were the King to pick that MUB, two of the three results of the measurement are expressed in terms of VAA states that Alice cannot distinguish, giving her a 50\\% chance of escaping the Mean King's cruelty. \n\n\n%With this in mind, Alice is able to retrodict the result of the King's measurement using a similar procedure to the above if the King chooses $m=1,3$ or $4$ as his measuring basis. If $m=2$, Alice would be able to resolve $\\ket{2_0\\bar{2_0}}$ of the basis by measuring $\\ket{\\phi_1}$, $\\ket{\\phi_5}$, or $\\ket{\\phi_9}$; but, since the remaining eigenstates of the basis are both superpositions of the indistinguishable VAA states, Alice would guess incorrectly with 50\\% probability. \n%It may be possible to improve upon the distinguishability of the VAA states by modifying the phases being applied within the experiment.  \n\n\n\\subsection{Quantum Gates}\\label{experiments:gates}\nUniversal quantum gates, which rely on the interaction between two or more photons, can be realized with non-linearities induced by measurements \\cite{knill2001scheme}. Quantum gates based on this approach, such as a CNOT between two qubits, have been realized experimentally for almost twenty years \\cite{gasparoni2004realization}. However, since then, the attempt to experimentally discover a wide range of quantum gates has continued due to the advancement of experimental resources which can deal with higher dimensional systems. \n\n\\paragraph{Heralded --}\nWe call a quantum gate heralded when only ancillary particles are detected, meaning that the outgoing particles are not measured. The photons exiting such a gate can continue into further components of a longer circuit. At the end of the circuit it is necessary to confirm that two photons have exited the gate, but not which path they followed.\nWe find that a higher dimensional version of the CNOT gate with a control qubit and a target qutrit ($\\text{CNOT}(2,3)$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot23]{experimentcounter}) can also be realized with two ancilla photons.\nFurther, we find a heralded Toffoli gate with four ancillas \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/toffoli]{experimentcounter}; see Fig.~\\ref{fig:heraldedgates}.\n\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n    \\subfloat[Heralded CNOT(2,3)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot23.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[Heralded Toffoli]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_toffoli.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for heralded quantum gates.}\n\t\\label{fig:heraldedgates}\n\\end{figure}\n\n%    \\item Toffoli (4 ancilla)\n%    \\item CNOT(2,3)\n\n\\paragraph{Reduced Input Space --}\nFor some tasks in which quantum gates are applied, there is some prior knowledge about the input state. This knowledge can be exploited to reduce the experimental resources required to perform the transformation \\cite{q_mem_advantage,NonDetLogicOperations}. A wide range of constraints on the input state can be encoded by our framework. Here we show examples of heralded quantum gates where a target qubit is prepared in the zero state before entering the gate. \n\n\\pytheus found gates $\\text{CNOT}(3,3)$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot33_0]{experimentcounter}, $\\text{CNOT}(4,4)$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/blob/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot44_0]{experimentcounter} and the Fredkin gate \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/fredkin_0]{experimentcounter} acting on a target input photon in the computational zero state; see Fig.~\\ref{fig:onzero}. A post-selected Fredkin gate on the full input space has been experimentally realized \\cite{fredkin16}.\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[heralded CNOT(3,3)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot33_0.pdf}}\n\t\\subfloat[heralded Fredkin]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_fredkin_0.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[heralded CNOT(4,4)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot44_0.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for heralded quantum gates with reduced input space.}\n\t\\label{fig:onzero}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\paragraph{Post-Selected --}\nWhen post-selecting a gate, all outgoing photons are detected and thus destroyed. Such a gate does not require as many resources as a heralded gate, but it imposes restrictions, such as not mixing the two output paths, on the remainder of the circuit, to ensure that the presence of a photon in each output of the gate can be ascertained.\n    \\pytheus found different post-selected high-dimensional CNOT gates, such as $\\text{CNOT}(2,3)$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/blob/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot23_post]{experimentcounter}, $\\text{CNOT}(2,4)$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot24_post]{experimentcounter}, $\\text{CNOT}(3,3)$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot33_post]{experimentcounter} and the Toffoli gate on a qutrit \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/toffoli_3d_post]{experimentcounter}; see Fig.~\\ref{fig:postselectedgates}.\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[CNOT(2,3)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot23_post.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[CNOT(2,4)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot24_post.pdf}}\\\\\n    \\subfloat[CNOT(3,3)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot33_post.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[3d Toffoli with two ancilla photons]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_toffoli_3d_post.pdf}} \n\t\\caption {Graphs for quantum gates with post-selection.}\n\t\\label{fig:postselectedgates}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Single Photon Sources for Quantum Gates}\n    Experiments exploiting single-photon sources as an additional resource for the construction of quantum gates have been previously demonstrated \\cite{spscnot}. Fig.~\\ref{fig:spsgates} displays graphs for a heralded $\\text{CNOT}(2,2)$ with two additional input photons \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/blob/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot22_sp]{experimentcounter}, a heralded $\\text{CNOT}(2,3)$ with three additional input photons \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot23_sp]{experimentcounter}, and a post-selected $\\text{CNOT}(2,3)$ with two additional input photons \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/Gates/cnot23_sp_post]{experimentcounter}.\\newline\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[heralded CNOT(2,2) s.p.s\\centering]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot22_sp.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[heralded CNOT(2,3) s.p.s\\centering]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot23_sp.pdf}}\\\\\n    \\subfloat[post-selected CNOT(2,3) s.p.s\\centering]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_cnot23_sp_post.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for quantum gates with single-photon sources as an additional resource.}\n\t\\label{fig:spsgates}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n \n\n\\subsection{Combinatorial Measures}\nIn this section, we demonstrate how \\pytheus can discover exceptional structures without computing the quantum state. This ability might be useful for finding experimental configurations with particular symmetries or properties that are interesting, independent of the resulting quantum state. Such metrics can also be combined with other objectives mentioned in the previous sections.\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Assembly Index}\nAs an example for structural property discovery, we consider the \\textit{assembly index}, which has been invented in chemistry for the search of extraterrestrial life \\cite{marshall2017probabilistic, marshall2021identifying}. Specifically, the assembly index counts the complexity of building up a combinatorial structure, for instance, molecules or --- in our case --- graphs. It counts the number of independent processes that are necessary to create a structure. The hypothesis is that a structure with a large assembly index cannot be formed by natural processes and would require complex (living) systems for its generation. Strong indications in favor of this hypothesis have been found in the study of millions of molecules on earth \\cite{marshall2021identifying}.\n\nOur goal here is to discover graphs with very high assembly indices. The assembly index is a discrete structural metric that cannot be optimized directly using gradients. However, we can use the weights of edges to transform the discrete metric into a continuously differentiable metric. A general procedure is to compute the average combinatorial value of the weighted graph from sampled discrete graphs. Here, the weights $|\\omega_i|^2$ are used as the probability for sampling discrete graphs. While this procedure is differential, it is computationally expensive as many sampled graphs need to be evaluated to obtain an average assembly index of the whole graph.\n\nAlternatively, here we restrict ourselves to graphs with exactly eight edges (with 4 \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/AssemblyIndex/assembly4]{experimentcounter} and 6 \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/AssemblyIndex/assembly6]{experimentcounter} vertices). Here, the eight highest-weighted edges are used to generate the graph, and in addition, weights are used to change the order of edges. The graphs in Fig.~\\ref{fig:assemblyindex} present graphs with very high assembly indices with 4 vertices and 8 edges as well as 6 vertices and 10 edges.\n\n \n\n\\begin{figure}\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[4 qubits, 8 edges,\\\\assembly index 8\\centering]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_assembly4.pdf}}\\hspace*{\\fill}\n\t\\subfloat[6 qubits, 10 edges,\\\\assembly index 10\\centering]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_assembly6.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for assembly index.}\n\t\\label{fig:assemblyindex}\n\\end{figure}\n\n%A deterministic loss function to maximize the assembly index is the \\textit{top-n-assembly} function. Maximizing this function aims to maximize the assembly index of the largest $n$ edges.\n%\\begin{align*}\n%    & topnAI = \\\\\n%    & \\sum_{n < i \\leq N}(AI(topn \\setminus \\{ e_n\\} \\cup \\{e_i\\}) - %AI(topn))|e_i|\\\\\n%    +& \\sum_{1 \\leq i \\leq n}(AI(topn) - AI(topn \\setminus \\{ e_i\\} \\cup %\\{e_{n+1}\\}))|e_i|\n%\\end{align*}\n%$e_1, e_2, ..., e_N$ are the weights of the graph ordered in decreasing absolute value. $topn = \\{ e_1, ..., e_n \\}$ are the largest n edges. $AI$ is the assembly index of a set of edges.\n%The first sum serves to \\textit{promote} edges that are not in the top $n$ edges but could be switched with edge $e_n$ to increase the AI. The second sum serves to \\textit{demote} edges that are part of the top $n$ edges but could be switched with $e_{n+1}$ to increase the AI.\n\n\n\\section{Outlook}\\label{sec:outlook}\nThis article uses a list of examples to showcase the broad range of possibilities of digital discovery in quantum optics. The goal to design one hundred novel and intriguing experiments has led us to collect a diverse set of tasks for which experimental setups could be designed. To make the discoveries possible, we expanded the theoretical framework underlying the algorithm and produced faster, more versatile open-source software. We hope that this work can be an inspiration for experimental physicists in two ways: (1) to explore some of the experiments as they are proposed in this article (2) to see that \\pytheus can be used to design experiments for a wide range of targets and for individually tailored specifications of experimental restrictions and resources. To explore particular examples that have not been covered in this article, the open-source library \\pytheus can be used. Many more avenues leave room for significant further exploration, particularly within the optimization for targets other than fidelity, as well as more specific experimental constraints. For this, the \\pytheus framework can readily be expanded in the future.\n\nA number of extensions that would be interesting include the discovery of experiments that maximize success probability in terms of heralding efficiency or Bell state measurement efficiency, especially as experimentally available technologies became increasingly powerful \\cite{bayerbach2022bell}. The potential of \\pytheus on suggesting experimental setups can pave the way to find experiments to simulate quantum states, which are nowadays merely realizable in extreme (thermodynamics) conditions, such as high pressure and low temperature~\\cite{Blume2012}. An exciting extension would be the analysation whether we can extend state generation to encoding the dymanics of a quantum state into the weights of the graphs. Along with this line of research, it is theoretically tantalizing to explore the putative correlation between the complexity of time-evolved states~\\cite{Parker2019} and the complexity of associated graphs as outputs of \\pytheus.%This would allow for the experimental investigation of nonequilibrium quantum systems, combined with the ability of \\pytheus to characterize different phases of a system, shown in Sec.~\\ref{sec:qsim}, may also allow one to exploit excited-state physics~\\cite{Lloyd-Hughes2021}, usually with an ultrashort lifetime in quantum systems, in advancing state-of-the-art quantum technologies. \n\nAs a final thought, we want to view our results through an additional lens. We have created a dataset of 100 hand-selected quantum experiments that are some aspects exceptional (which \\pytheus has discovered). This dataset might be large enough for highly efficient artificial intelligence algorithms to bootstrap an intuition of what properties make an experiment interesting, and allow them to produce proposals for new, hopefully equally interesting quantum experiments. It would sure be exciting to investigate the physical properties of the proposals that the machine believes are \\textit{interesting}. In the best case, it could act as an inspiration for new ideas for the human scientist \\cite{krenn2022scientific, rudolph2023terry}.\n\n\\tocless\\section{Acknowledgment}\nThe authors thank Jian-Wei Wang and Jake Bulmer for their useful comments. The authors thank Matthias B\u00e4r for his support in software development and Jhon Alejandro Monta\u00f1ez for help in an early version of the software.\nS.S. thanks the Galileo Galilei Institute for Theoretical Physics for hospitality during the completion of this work. T.J. and E.K. acknowledge the support of the Canada Research Chairs (CRC) and Max Planck-University of Ottawa Centre for Extreme and Quantum Photonics.\nN.T. is a recipient of an Australian Research Council Discovery Early Career Researcher Award (DE220101082). This work was partially supported by the Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence for Quantum Computation and Communication Technology (Grant No. CE170100012). \n\n%% there is no fixed style in Quantum journal, just chose one looks good\n%\\bibliographystyle{apsrev4-2}\n\\bibliographystyle{unsrtnat}\n\\bibliography{main.bib}\n%\\printbibliography\n\\end{document}\n\n<END OF PYTHEUS PAPER>\n\nYou are an expert quantum physicist judging the novelty and feasibility of research ideas.\n\nYour colleague is trying to come up with interesting and novel targets to explore in the field of quantum optics.\n\nThe final goal is to design an experimental setup using the Pytheus tool (with all of its applications and capabilities explained in the paper given above).\nThis target could be a measurement, transformation, or protocol in the domain of quantum optics and it has to be achievable with the Pytheus tool and the associated experimental techniques.\n\nPytheus can design new experiments for quantum state transformations, quantum communication protocols, quantum measurements. The experiments are done with photons, often using SPDC or single-photon sources and single-photon detectors, coincidence detections.\n\nPlease generate a response to the following research idea:\n\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. Our target is to teleport an unknown qubit injected at node A across the torus to node B with high fidelity once a noncontractible entanglement-swap loop percolates across the lattice.\n\nYou take the role of the domain expert writing constructive feedback (can include positive and negative aspects). Carefully consider if the physics of the proposed experiment is sound and if the experimental setup is feasible.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\nDo not accept suggestions that propose a state generation as a target.\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (explain your understanding of the proposed experiment and your reasoning on its feasibility and novelty.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (Provide your final feedback as a self-contained two to three sentence response (not referencing your previous statements). Do not suggest changing the idea to one that has state generation as a target.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (explain your understanding of the proposed experiment and your reasoning on its feasibility and novelty.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (provide your final feedback as a self-contained two to three sentence response (not referencing your previous statements).)\n",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal outlines a device\u2010level design problem\u2014finding a static layout of Bell\u2010pair sources and Bell\u2010measurement modules on a toroidal grid that, once postselected, percolates entanglement to enable teleportation from A to B. It fits squarely into PyTheus\u2019s strength for automating networked entanglement\u2010swapping and measurement\u2010induced protocols, and though it will be resource\u2010intensive it is conceptually sound and novel in its use of percolation theory.  \nAction: accept  \nAction Input: This is an intriguing, well\u2010posed quantum communication task that leverages PyTheus\u2019s network and measurement design capabilities. Optimizing for a percolation threshold on a toroidal lattice to ensure high\u2010fidelity teleportation is both novel and within the framework\u2019s scope."
